column1: ","Urban Gardening & Project-Based Learning...

DEUP Learning Center is a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization providing access to the incredible world of project-based learning (PBL) in a safe and supervised after-school setting. Beginning in the Fall of 2014 we will be servicing under-resourced,

at-risk students in the South Los Angeles area. Our programming will be interest-centered and project rich. Students will gain valuable hands-on experiences in the following areas: urban gardening, greening, recycling, food storage, water filtration, solar energy, electric transportation, carpentry, sustainable development, computer/communications technology, home economics and self-reliance. In addition, we will still be having lots of FUN!!! Arts & crafts, games, caroms, ping-pong, basketball...you name it! The DEUP Learning Center After-School Program will be an exciting place to be in 2014. We will be ready to love, respect and provide services that enrich the lives of our children. We will operate Mon-Fri, for the entire school year. Our Summer program dates and times will be announced.

Mission Statement: The DEUP Learning Center is being established to provide zero cost after-school and summer programming to under-resourced, at-risk youth throughout South Los Angeles. Our mission is to create project driven after-school learning environments that inspire and foster healthy thinking and living in ways that equip youth to confidently confront the issues of poverty and disadvantage.

SEPTEMBER 2014 - This is indeed a very ambitious project, but this is exactly why we’re here. We need your help. If we are unable to answer this call, and open these doors… right here in South Los Angeles, it just means that we have to stand on the sidelines…again to watch yet another generation of inner-city youth withdraw and retreat back into the clutch of poverty and disadvantage. The youth of South Los Angeles deserve so much more than this. They deserve great teachers and they deserve great programs.  We believe that the children of South Los Angeles have a natural right to exercise their minds in ways that promote positive change for their communities.  DEUP is determined and willing to stand up for the cause of change in the inner-city and offer a creative and healthy after-school setting, where the emotional and educational well being of South L.A.’s children is always top priority.
Come August of 2014, these doors will swing wide open…and we will embrace, support and befriend the community with all our heart.  We ask that you stand with us to make a difference.
DEUP Learning Center…We are transforming the environment with love and some good honest, interest-centered education. Keep reading to find out how the funds will be used.
What will the funds be used for?

Having secured our first property in South Los Angeles (photos below), our goal is to now obtain the funding that will enable us to prep the property for use and also support the first 12 months of operation. Please consider helping us open our doors by the Fall of summer 2014. All donations are tax deductible. Costs will include:

Exterior (sandblasting, stucco, paint, security gate and lights, concrete walkway & driveway, handicap access ramp/railing, ground prep for laying of sod, landscaping, garden area, outdoor sink, in-ground basketball goal, recreational area w/bench, striping for parking area and basketball court, parking signs and signage for building)
Interior - (Install a handicap accessible bathroom, shelves,  cabinets, refrigerators, upright freezers, storage bins, office furniture, desks, chairs)
Classroom materials (whiteboards, desks, chairs, project tables, projector and screen, laptop computers, iPads, ""Chromebooks, software, educational materials and books)

Project materials (landscape and garden tools, water hoses, electrician and carpenter tool sets, cordless electric lawn mover, electric weed wacker, work benches, wood for raised beds, greenhouse materials, mason jars, food dehydrators, sewing machines, patterns and material, electric bike components, solar energy components, water treatment components, electrical components)

Healthy foods and snacks

2) OUR CAMPAIGN

OUR GOAL
column9: >We would like to publish a free guide on learning disabilities which include: “Dys” disorders (dyslexia, dysphasia, dyspraxia, dyscalculia, dysgraphia, dysorthography and dyschronia), Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD), Autism and High Intellectual Potential (1/3 of gifted children fail school as the actual schooling system doesn’t recognize their specific needs).
column10:
>This 160 pages long brochure embraces a global approach and takes into consideration early sign of learning differences, treatments and nutrition and gives practical advises on after-school activities, homework and holiday. It will be given for free to parents, teachers, paediatricians and therapist. We would like to have one set of print in French and one in English.

OUR STORY
column11: >We are parents of an 11 years old son who is dyslexic and dyspraxic and of a 9 years old daughter who has a high intellectual potential. Our eldest had to step down two degrees and go to a specialised school while our youngest who started a phobia against school, stepped up one degree but still has stomach aches most mornings before classes. Life hasn’t been easy for neither of them (hasn’t been easy on us either if I may say).
column12: >Early in time, we realised that their learning differences weren’t well known, let alone taken into account, by teachers, paediatricians and most therapists and instead of whining (a great temptation at first, along with screaming and weeping), we decided to do something about it.
column13: >For two years, we spent evenings after evenings over books at the university library and came up with our 160 pages long guide on learning differences.
column14:
>As our main goal is to have a better dissemination of the information, to give away free copies to everyone concerned by the problematic seemed the way forward. Therefore, we have been looking for advertisers to insert publicities in our brochure to finance it.

We are starting to get some success but yet, not enough, to accomplish all our goals which are:

column1: <li style=""text-align: justify
column2: >Print the French version of the guide in 50’000 copies in France, in 20’000 copies in Switzerland and Belgium. Our wish is to have them financed by publicity, sponsorships and donations in order to give away free copies to parents, teachers and therapists.

column1: <li style=""text-align: justify
column2: >Set up an International Internet site to be the platform where parents, teachers,   scientists of different countries communicate and share experiences.

column1: <li style=""text-align: justify
column2: >Have the guide translated in English and German and other languages if we have the financial means for it. Have it available in PDF to be downloaded for free from our Internet Site.

column1: <li style=""text-align: justify
column2: >Create a database of numeric/IT solutions and tools useful to children with learning differences by age and school degrees.

column1: • Create a database on scientific studies on learning disabilities.
• Produce a software to help early diagnosis of these types of learning differences.

column3: >Clearly, we need money, money, money (don’t we all!) but not only. If you are a talented illustrator or web designer on DreamWeaver, we would be very grateful to have your external input to help us in making our site colourful and joyful.
column4: >And also, please spread the word about this crowd fundraising and let us know what you think of our projects and ways to make it better. Every contribution counts! THANK YOU!

Life hasn’t been easy for neither of them (hasn’t been easy on us either if I may say).Early in time, we realised that their learning differences weren’t well known, let alone taken into account, by teachers, paediatricians and most therapists and instead of whining (a great temptation at first, along with screaming and weeping), we decided to do something about it.For two years, we spent evenings after evenings over books at the university library and came up with our 160 pages long guide on learning differences.As our main goal is to have a better dissemination of the information, to give away free copies to everyone concerned by the problematic seemed the way forward. Therefore, we have been looking for advertisers to insert publicities in our brochure to finance it.We are starting to get some success but yet, not enough, to accomplish all our goals which are:

Print the French version of the guide in 50’000 copies in France, in 20’000 copies in Switzerland and Belgium. Our wish is to have them financed by publicity, sponsorships and donations in order to give away free copies to parents, teachers and therapists.
Set up an International Internet site to be the platform where parents, teachers,   scientists of different countries communicate and share experiences.
Have the guide translated in English and German and other languages if we have the financial means for it. Have it available in PDF to be downloaded for free from our Internet Site.
Create a database of numeric/IT solutions and tools useful to children with learning differences by age and school degrees.
Create a database on scientific studies on learning disabilities.
Produce a software to help early diagnosis of these types of learning differences.

HOW TO HELP USClearly, we need money, money, money (don’t we all!) but not only. If you are a talented illustrator or web designer on DreamWeaver, we would be very grateful to have your external input to help us in making our site colourful and joyful.And also, please spread the word about this crowd fundraising and let us know what you think of our projects and ways to make it better. Every contribution counts! THANK YOU!3) ENGLISH DOCUMENTARY: TYRON AND LYNDON BROWN: 2 BROTHERS SUFFERING FROM GLOBAL DYSPRAXIA",0.0,3,"2 Campaigns
|","Genève, Switzerland",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/learning-differences-it-isn-t-always-easy-to-learn/pica

About me

Hi. My name is Maghen and I'm 22 years old. After recently
backpacking Ghana this summer, I'm heading towards my next big adventure in
column2: >January to India with World Literacy Canada. I'm a small town girl
column3: > born and raised in Kingsville, Ontario before moving away to Ottawa
column4: >for University where I fell in love with international relations and the power of
column5: >communications on a global scale. In my four years completing my
column6: >undergrad I spent a lot of time with different volunteer networks that
column7: >have helped me realize my desire to travel and chase the unknown, or
column8: >rather to question what hasn't been questioned. I'm curious and
column9: >constantly seeking my next challenge as an avid adventurer and
column10: >learner. I'm a suckor for a strong cup of coffee and a good playlist.

column1: <div>

Volunteer history: I'm motivated by the possibilities of impact and
systemic change. I started volunteering with Engineers without Borders
in my second year doing public relations and publicity. Since then I
have volunteered with numerous NGOs that include Farm Radio
International, One Days Wages, CUSO-VSO and Ghana Medical Help.
Working within the realm of communications, research and fundraising I
have been able to acquire a new skill set in various professional
settings. The appeal in volunteering to me comes from the desire to
learn from failure and make new connections from systems that exist at
a local level. During my volunteer internship in India I will be working with an
organization (WLC) that puts a strong and relevant emphasis on
empowering young woman in education. Despite a dominant narrative of
prosperity and upward mobility, the eight poorest states of India
contain more people living in absolute poverty than in Africa’s 26
poorest countries combined. With income disparities widening and
intensifying gender inequality, it is important to continue providing
hope and opportunity to the 645 million citizens who have no access to
India’s new found wealth. The programs that WLC organizes and
facilitates offer adult literacy classes, access to government
programs and an advocacy system that is founded on strengthening the
ties of men and woman in rural communities to work together
Why World Literacy Canada?

World Literacy Canada has programs that promote innovation and change in a
way that aligns closely to my views on development, politics and
social justice. In 2013-14, World Literacy Canada’s India Project will
reach 425 urban and rural communities in Uttar Pradesh, India. It will
have a direct impact on the lives of over 42,000 women and children,
and indirectly it will multiply to serve thousands more.   Within each
community World Literacy Canada organizes a Mahila Mandal (women’s
group) to oversee the project.  The current 425 Mahila Mandal’s, with
a membership of 14,000, have been democratically elected to support
the Adult Literacy Classes (ALC) and Early Childhood Learning
(Balwadi) Program in their community.

In their efforts to make change, they are also making their programs
readily accessible and relevant. I selected WLC to participate in the
internship because I believe in their programs. I believe in change
founded on dignity and advancing human rights discourse.

Where the money is going:

WLC offers a volunteer based internship meaning for the four months I
will be living, I will not have an income.

Your donations will go to the placement fee and living accommodations.

I am working every day to afford the internship and all of its
wonderful possibilities and am extremely grateful for every addition
thought and dollar that goes towards my campaign.
The Impact

While in India I will be working on a communications project where I
will be  responsible for collecting “stories from the ground” for
various forms of communication including reports, social media and
fundraising tools. I will be conducting interviews with partners and
program beneficiaries to contribute to communication initiatives.
Other components of the internship include:

• Comprehensive editing on all communication’s pieces
• Blog regularly on the work being done by WLC in Varanasi
• Provide high quality photos and/or videos of WLC’s India programs
Closing Statement

If you've made it this far in my pitch or if you skipped all of this
and just watched the video, I hope you're convinced regardless of how
much this internship means to me. I am so grateful for the time you
have taken right now to read/watch my testimonial for my fundraising
project.

Going to Ghana was such a humbling experience and one that challenged
my thinking on poverty, education and health care. Please, I encourage
you to consider donating to my next step towards a career in
international development and communications.

SHORT SUMMARY
A youth led, child centered and for
children grassroots initiative whose mission is to rescue children from
violence, hazardous work and to promote good health and education to vulnerable
children. Values are at the core of everything we do. Our registration number
is 104414 in the Republic of Zambia.
1 in 5 children aged 2 to 5years in my
community village is out of school and spending over 14hours on the
streets  with a sibling or mother or grandmother. In 2014 alone, over 60
children in my village missed out on early learning due to lack of financial
support for them to enroll in early education centres. Nearly 60% of the
households are living below $1.25 per day and go with 1 meal a day, sometimes
none. This has resulted in children being found where adults are doing their
usual business and this has led to many abuses including physical and sexual
abuse of the children. Taverns, bars, highways, sand mines and markets are not
safe places for children.
Youth First Development is running a
community early education centre to protect children from these vices whilst
intervening on their education and health needs.
Currently, our centre has 60 children
that were previously in the markets, bars and taverns with parents on the
streets, abused and neglected children including disabled children. All these
have been left out in the education system and have not benefited from
government social assistance programs. This project will reduce the number of
children missing out on education from 1 in 10 to only 1 in 3 children. We need
U$8,000 to achieve this.
WHAT WE NEED &
WHAT YOU GET
The project needs U$8, 000 to improve
its centre building, 60 chairs and tables, play materials (10 sets consisting
dolls and other child friendly toys), learning materials and teaching aids
(flip charts, picture charts, crayons, chalkboard).
To show our great appreciation, we give
locally made crafts and artifacts to our supporters in addition to giving you
an opportunity to come out and be part of our field programs in the community
such as reading for the children, playing field games with them including
painting alongside the children etc. As a way of thanking you, YFD will
intentionally recognize your contributions on our website and in annual reports.
ALL the funds will go towards ""My
World My Child"" protection program in Mulimba Village in Chibombo, 90km
from Lusaka the capital city of Zambia.
THE IMPACT
This project will reduce from 1 in 10
children without access to early learning opportunity to 1 in 3 and double the
number of children that are accessing education in safe environments. The
opportunity also reduces by more than half the children at risk of abuse and
exploitation in the community. This is your to contribute to cause that will
change the world, and support better lifestyles for children in need, giving
them a chance to financially independent in their future.
That One Child Matters the Most! Over
the last 3 years, we have supported over 180 children access early
learning opportunities in their communities. For just U$450 in 2013, we
supported 2 children living with disability to access wheelchairs, enroll in
school and increase their families’ access to food and safe waters and
sanitation. We have also rescued from early marriages and supported them to
return to school while supporting them create their own wealth through
financial inclusion programs. More than 233 young people have been sensitized
on the sexual and reproductive health rights through trainings, campaigns and
life skills.
We are looking not only for how much
you can give to this cause but how much more you can share with your friends,
family and networks. At YFD, we accept all forms of support and are happy to
have you mention us and our work in your social networks.
We urge you to use the Indiegogo share
tools to help us achieve our goals. With your support, we believe that one
child at a time will grow, develop and become a responsible and financially
independent citizen not just of Zambia but a global citizen.

The mission of Trumpets Not Guns is to provide inner city schools in New Orleans with musical instruments, band uniforms, books and whatever else is needed to keep the music playing.

The vision of TNG was created by New Orleans native Lisa Grillot and her husband John. They are the parents of eight children and have a passion for the music of their home town. TNG is a certified non profit in the State of Louisiana. 

The documentary arm of the organization, TNG Productions, was an idea by filmmaker James Demaria who strives to keep the culture of New Orleans alive through the archiving and dissemination of its unique musical traditions.

New Orleans is the place where America's music took root, and we as modern-day Americans need to keep it growing. At a time when gun violence is an increasingly common intrusion into the lives of our youth, our goal is to try to place an instrument in the hands of a child who might otherwise find the way of the streets more alluring. So you, as a contributor, will not only help to save part of New Orleans culture but also attempt to preserve a child's future.
In the words of Louis ""Pops"" Armstrong, another New Orleans native:
Help make movies with TNG Productions.

James Demaria is a professional photographer and documentary filmmaker from NYC who has called New Orleans home twice in his life. After moving his family back to New York, post Hurricane Katrina, his mission has been to shine a light on the culture and music of the Crescent City through his accomplished photography and video projects. His most recent documentary is entitled The Key To Me: The Paul And Shelly Sanchez Story and will air on PBS this coming March.

James has teamed up with Trumpets Not Guns to start his latest documentary endeavor, TRAD. This film analyzes the ongoing efforts to keep the roots music flourishing in the TRAD-itional manner. In a city flooded by musicians from the outside world, James endeavors to highlight the true, native players of New Orleans music. The film centers on Jazz saxophone player Calvin Johnson Jr., who comes from a long line of NOLA musicians. In TRAD, Calvin discuss the traditions which not only shape the music but also shape the lives of the people who live in the thriving musical communities. Interviews thus far include such notable performers as Irvin Mayfield, Kidd Jordan, Roger Lewis, Carl Leblanc, Debbie Davis and Paul Sanchez. There is also a performance filmed at historic Preservation Hall where Calvin was the youngest person to lead a band in the hallowed space.
Now it's up to you.

We have the vision, but we need the tools. By helping to finance TRAD, you will be helping to preserve an art form that is truly American in nature. Only in New Orleans has the blending of African, European and Native American traditions created such a unique and irreplaceable form of Jazz. Without care and cultivation, that art form will be forever lost. TNG recognizes that students need instruments and young artists need to be supported. Our first TNG Production aims to bring awareness and inspiration but to that end, we need the financial support of the community. The funds that are raised will help cover the costs of everything from plane tickets to sound engineers. It will cover editors and production assistants. It will allow James Demaria to take this film to completion so that the vibrant traditional music of New Orleans can galvanize a new generation.

The goal of Youth Leading the World (YLTW) is to build a movement of inspired leaders with the skills to create an environmentally sustainable, spiritually fulfilling and socially just human presence on the planet and become leaders of positive change. This project aims to do this through the following four ways:

column2: >1.  Inform youth about local and global environmental challenges
>2.  Allow youth to reflect and go through a visioning process of how they want their community and the world to be sustainable and just
>3.  Give space for change to happen through creative thinking and brainstorming
>4. Provide support for action planning and practical goal setting for both personal and community change.

column1: YLTW is a three-day intensive process in which young people explore local and global issues of sustainability, measure and understand their own ecological footprint and work on action plans to make change in their lives, schools and communities.
column6: Itemid=260)"" rel=""noopener nofollow"">OzGreen, an Australian non-profit, designed this process and have had great success in using this process as a way to integrate transformative learning and leadership process that fast tracks our transition to sustainability. The curriculum expressly integrates transformative learning and leading processes in order to prepare and support youth in making deeply rooted commitments to action now.

column1: Youth participants will be informed about local and global environmental challenges like climate change and led through a visioning process for how they want their community and the world to be. With that vision in mind, they brainstorm and have time for creative thinking to identify opportunities for change. The experience will end with action planning and goal setting for personal and community change. They will present their action plans to their other classmates and teachers.

Every year, YLTW conducts an annual congress in which young people from more than 90 global locations are digitally linked together throughout the three days.  We want to plug Costa Rican youth into this process!

On September 3-5 we will hold YLTW in Costa Rica for the first time. It will be held in the small rural town of Mastatal, on a local organic farm called Finca Siempre Verde. Finca Siempre Verde was founded by Marcos Garcia Guzman and is a rural ecotourism destination and an organic farm developing permaculture. It is one of four farms in Mastatal that is dedicated to sustainability and a resilient community.
Participants will attend from three different local high schools: CTP La Gloria, the high school in Mastatal, and the high school in Zapaton.
To prepare for this global event, we have hired a trained instructor for  YLTW, to train Marcos and three other local people to serve as facilitators.

Facilitators will learn how to lead YLTW, but also gain skills in leadership, project development, and communication which will allow them to continue this work and support the youth in the work they choose to do after being a part of this program.
Who are we?

My name is Emily McVey and I grew up and go to college in Southern California. I am a student studying Earth System Science, Global Sustainability, and Community Engagement. While in school, I also worked on campus developing our Global Sustainability Resource Center, which is a student-led initiative to foster a campus culture of sustainability. Last Spring, I was the Student Coordinator of the UCI Costa Rica Program and traveled to Costa Rica in March of 2013, which is how I was connected with this community. Mastatal is a small town with about 150 locals. It has four organic farms that host volunteers and interns and educate about sustainability and resiliency. I am living at Finca Siempre Verde as a farm intern from June 13-September 12 and I am working with Marcos Garcia Guzman, the founder of Finca Siempre Verde.

Marcos Garcia is playing a large role in this project. He grew up in Mastatal and has a very good connection with the community. He lives on his parent’s land and runs Finca Siempre Verde, an organic farm. He has been a part of the local government in the past and is involved in many different projects in the community, including the recent conceptualization of an organization that will be called Mastatal Verde Regeneracion. The following is a comment from him about why having YLTW here is important to him:

column2: >Living in a remote area and not having much contact with the outside can be a big limitation for a small town and especially for the young population. My main reason for wanting to have Youth Leading the World here in my community is for youth to gain knowledge and the desire to be future leaders in their communities, as this is necessary for this type of population. Having the ability to have a program like this will be opening a big door for these young people to learn new concepts and become leaders in sustainability. It will be a unique experience and they can then carry this knowledge to the rest of the community and make a change in a larger way with many people. Besides this, the place we would like to hold this program, Finca Siempre Verde, is an organic farm with many important sustainable-based techniques. Giving them the chance to stay here will enrich these students, giving more experience and knowledge for the participants.

column1: What do we need?
We need a total of $1,600.

column2: >$960 Food and Lodging for the 12 students in the ecotourism class at CTP La Gloria. These students don't have the resources to come and stay at Finca Siempre Verde for YLTW and Marcos doesn't have the resources to sponsor them. It is $80 per student for the 3 days.

>$400  Food and Lodging for 5 students from Zapaton. These students don't have the resources to come and stay at Finca Siempre Verde for YLTW and Marcos doesn't have the resources to sponsor them. It is $80 per student for the 3 days.
>$80 Lunches for the 4 students from Mastatal attending the three days. They go home each night. It will cost $20 per student.
>$160 Trainer food and lodging for when he comes and stays at Finca Siempre Verde to train faciilitators.

column1: We were fortunate enough to recieve a $1,000 grant and so now we only need to raise at least $600!

If we are not fully funded, but are close to goal amount, we will go through with the project. If we are far off from our goal amount, we will still hold YLTW, but it will be at one of the schools, so we will use the funds to  provude transportation and food for the students.
What will the impact be?

I am creating this campaign page from Mastatal, Costa Rica.  It is a very special community. It resides against a national park called La Cangreja. It is a beautiful community, but there are not many opportunities for jobs. Not only is this a problem for adults currently living here, but also for the youth that will be out of school very soon. Many of them are likely to leave for nearby cities like Puriscal and San Jose to find jobs. The students from La Gloria and Zapaton come from other neighboring communities facing the same concerns as Mastatal. I care about sharing the YLTW process with young people here because I believe they will be key in the regeneration of their communities, and they could continue this work as facilitators in the future and leaders in their communities. This would allow them to facilitate the process for youth in other communities throughout Costa Rica and empower people in both rural and urban settings.

I am starting this project because it is too late to not be engaging our hearts in the crises we are facing. I care deeply about the planet and all life forms on it and want to create a world where the environment doesn’t need protecting. I feel that facilitating the situation for youth to feel the urgency and magnitude of both the loss and opportunity we have in this moment can be transformational and empowering.  We need processes that allow us to acknowledge, experience, and move through grief as communities in order to clear the way for informed and inspired action to build a sustainable, resilient, and just community both locally and globally. I am looking empower both the facilitators and the participants to continue this work and continue holding YLTW congresses throughout Costa Rica.

The students we will be working with live in different communities around Mastatal and are all facing similar struggles. The communities lack jobs and many young people are leaving towns to find jobs in larger cities like Puriscal and San Jose. In Mastatal, there is an ongoing effort from local leaders to form a non-profit organization to regenerate the community. This program will be a way to involve the youth from these communities in the effort to regenerate and create sustainable, resilient communities. It is important to give them the opportunity to create a vision of how they want their community to be and identify actions that could be taken to achieve those visions.

The purpose of this project is to give these students an experience that will launch them into taking action in their communities. In Mastatal, some leaders have already started taking action to help with the issues they are facing by working on creating an organization, but the youth haven’t been involved. Marcos Garcia wrote a comment about the organization that has been in the process of forming over the last few months:

column2: >I live in Mastatal, a small town of a population of 150 people a bit isolated but with very good people. For the past month some of the community leaders have seen the need to have a group representing identity of our community. In a few days we are having our local group legalized and we will be ready to work and find the right contacts for a long list of needs for our community. This group will be called Mastatal Verde Regeneracion and the mission will be to provide social and environmental assistance in our community. Mastatal Verde Regeneracion will seek funds nationally and internationally.

column1: Since some students will not be from Mastatal, but other local towns, they will be able to see what Mastatal is doing to regenerate their community. It will give them the opportunity to see what they could do and what they can bring back to their community in both skills and ideas.

When YLTW is held again next year, the students involved in this year’s program will be able to train as facilitators and host the next YLTW on their own. They can also hold more YLTW in other areas of Costa Rica and expand their impact. We hope that we will be able to inspire these students to start groups in their schools, or even their communities so that they will become leaders and start make change and inspiring others. Hosting these students at Finca Siempre Verde and exposing them to the concept of visioning and practical goal setting for change through actions will be seeding future leaders of these communities. This will support ongoing efforts to regenerate these communities and start the fire for global change to create a socially and environmentally just world.
Other Ways You Can Help
Please share this page with family and friends and let them know how important it is so we can reach our goal. Thanks for your help!!!
","What is Youth Leading the World?

The goal of Youth Leading the World (YLTW) is to build a movement of inspired leaders with the skills to create an environmentally sustainable, spiritually fulfilling and socially just human presence on the planet and become leaders of positive change. This project aims to do this through the following four ways:
1.  Inform youth about local and global environmental challenges
2.  Allow youth to reflect and go through a visioning process of how they want their community and the world to be sustainable and just
3.  Give space for change to happen through creative thinking and brainstorming
4. Provide support for action planning and practical goal setting for both personal and community change.

YLTW is a three-day intensive process in which young people explore local and global issues of sustainability, measure and understand their own ecological footprint and work on action plans to make change in their lives, schools and communities. OzGreen, an Australian non-profit, designed this process and have had great success in using this process as a way to integrate transformative learning and leadership process that fast tracks our transition to sustainability. The curriculum expressly integrates transformative learning and leading processes in order to prepare and support youth in making deeply rooted commitments to action now.

Youth participants will be informed about local and global environmental challenges like climate change and led through a visioning process for how they want their community and the world to be. With that vision in mind, they brainstorm and have time for creative thinking to identify opportunities for change. The experience will end with action planning and goal setting for personal and community change. They will present their action plans to their other classmates and teachers.

Every year, YLTW conducts an annual congress in which young people from more than 90 global locations are digitally linked together throughout the three days.  We want to plug Costa Rican youth into this process!
Bringing YLTW to Costa Rica

On September 3-5 we will hold YLTW in Costa Rica for the first time. It will be held in the small rural town of Mastatal, on a local organic farm called Finca Siempre Verde. Finca Siempre Verde was founded by Marcos Garcia Guzman and is a rural ecotourism destination and an organic farm developing permaculture. It is one of four farms in Mastatal that is dedicated to sustainability and a resilient community.
Participants will attend from three different local high schools: CTP La Gloria, the high school in Mastatal, and the high school in Zapaton.
To prepare for this global event, we have hired a trained instructor for  YLTW, to train Marcos and three other local people to serve as facilitators.

Facilitators will learn how to lead YLTW, but also gain skills in leadership, project development, and communication which will allow them to continue this work and support the youth in the work they choose to do after being a part of this program.
Who are we?

My name is Emily McVey and I grew up and go to college in Southern California. I am a student studying Earth System Science, Global Sustainability, and Community Engagement. While in school, I also worked on campus developing our Global Sustainability Resource Center, which is a student-led initiative to foster a campus culture of sustainability. Last Spring, I was the Student Coordinator of the UCI Costa Rica Program and traveled to Costa Rica in March of 2013, which is how I was connected with this community. Mastatal is a small town with about 150 locals. It has four organic farms that host volunteers and interns and educate about sustainability and resiliency. I am living at Finca Siempre Verde as a farm intern from June 13-September 12 and I am working with Marcos Garcia Guzman, the founder of Finca Siempre Verde.

Marcos Garcia is playing a large role in this project. He grew up in Mastatal and has a very good connection with the community. He lives on his parent’s land and runs Finca Siempre Verde, an organic farm. He has been a part of the local government in the past and is involved in many different projects in the community, including the recent conceptualization of an organization that will be called Mastatal Verde Regeneracion. The following is a comment from him about why having YLTW here is important to him:

Living in a remote area and not having much contact with the outside can be a big limitation for a small town and especially for the young population. My main reason for wanting to have Youth Leading the World here in my community is for youth to gain knowledge and the desire to be future leaders in their communities, as this is necessary for this type of population. Having the ability to have a program like this will be opening a big door for these young people to learn new concepts and become leaders in sustainability. It will be a unique experience and they can then carry this knowledge to the rest of the community and make a change in a larger way with many people. Besides this, the place we would like to hold this program, Finca Siempre Verde, is an organic farm with many important sustainable-based techniques. Giving them the chance to stay here will enrich these students, giving more experience and knowledge for the participants.
What do we need?
We need a total of $1,600.

$960 Food and Lodging for the 12 students in the ecotourism class at CTP La Gloria. These students don't have the resources to come and stay at Finca Siempre Verde for YLTW and Marcos doesn't have the resources to sponsor them. It is $80 per student for the 3 days.

$400  Food and Lodging for 5 students from Zapaton. These students don't have the resources to come and stay at Finca Siempre Verde for YLTW and Marcos doesn't have the resources to sponsor them. It is $80 per student for the 3 days.
$80 Lunches for the 4 students from Mastatal attending the three days. They go home each night. It will cost $20 per student.
$160 Trainer food and lodging for when he comes and stays at Finca Siempre Verde to train faciilitators.
We were fortunate enough to recieve a $1,000 grant and so now we only need to raise at least $600!

If we are not fully funded, but are close to goal amount, we will go through with the project. If we are far off from our goal amount, we will still hold YLTW, but it will be at one of the schools, so we will use the funds to  provude transportation and food for the students.
What will the impact be?

I am creating this campaign page from Mastatal, Costa Rica.  It is a very special community. It resides against a national park called La Cangreja. It is a beautiful community, but there are not many opportunities for jobs. Not only is this a problem for adults currently living here, but also for the youth that will be out of school very soon. Many of them are likely to leave for nearby cities like Puriscal and San Jose to find jobs. The students from La Gloria and Zapaton come from other neighboring communities facing the same concerns as Mastatal. I care about sharing the YLTW process with young people here because I believe they will be key in the regeneration of their communities, and they could continue this work as facilitators in the future and leaders in their communities. This would allow them to facilitate the process for youth in other communities throughout Costa Rica and empower people in both rural and urban settings.

I am starting this project because it is too late to not be engaging our hearts in the crises we are facing. I care deeply about the planet and all life forms on it and want to create a world where the environment doesn’t need protecting. I feel that facilitating the situation for youth to feel the urgency and magnitude of both the loss and opportunity we have in this moment can be transformational and empowering.  We need processes that allow us to acknowledge, experience, and move through grief as communities in order to clear the way for informed and inspired action to build a sustainable, resilient, and just community both locally and globally. I am looking empower both the facilitators and the participants to continue this work and continue holding YLTW congresses throughout Costa Rica.

The students we will be working with live in different communities around Mastatal and are all facing similar struggles. The communities lack jobs and many young people are leaving towns to find jobs in larger cities like Puriscal and San Jose. In Mastatal, there is an ongoing effort from local leaders to form a non-profit organization to regenerate the community. This program will be a way to involve the youth from these communities in the effort to regenerate and create sustainable, resilient communities. It is important to give them the opportunity to create a vision of how they want their community to be and identify actions that could be taken to achieve those visions.

The purpose of this project is to give these students an experience that will launch them into taking action in their communities. In Mastatal, some leaders have already started taking action to help with the issues they are facing by working on creating an organization, but the youth haven’t been involved. Marcos Garcia wrote a comment about the organization that has been in the process of forming over the last few months:

For the past month some of the community leaders have seen the need to have a group representing identity of our community. In a few days we are having our local group legalized and we will be ready to work and find the right contacts for a long list of needs for our community. This group will be called Mastatal Verde Regeneracion and the mission will be to provide social and environmental assistance in our community. Mastatal Verde Regeneracion will seek funds nationally and internationally.

Since some students will not be from Mastatal, but other local towns, they will be able to see what Mastatal is doing to regenerate their community. It will give them the opportunity to see what they could do and what they can bring back to their community in both skills and ideas.

When YLTW is held again next year, the students involved in this year’s program will be able to train as facilitators and host the next YLTW on their own. They can also hold more YLTW in other areas of Costa Rica and expand their impact. We hope that we will be able to inspire these students to start groups in their schools, or even their communities so that they will become leaders and start make change and inspiring others. Hosting these students at Finca Siempre Verde and exposing them to the concept of visioning and practical goal setting for change through actions will be seeding future leaders of these communities. column1: ","Young Hero TalesFREE Self-Defense Stories and Games to Help Keep Children safe and Confident
Hi, I’m Sarah, a certified Martial Arts and Self-Defense instructor, and former police woman. I’ve been working with children for almost 10 year focusing on
providing them with Self-Defense tools. Tools such
as:
Self-Confidence
Awareness of dangerous situations
Notions of personal space
Listening to their instincts
Dealing with peer pressure
Using their voice and physical
capabilities to protect
themselves
Strengthening the bond between children and their
caregivers so children are able to ask for help when they need it
My goal is to provide as many children with these Self-Defense tools. I’m doing
this by using the timeless art of storytelling and playing games.
I’ve created specialized “fairy tales” to help children develop
and strengthen these abilities.
Each of these short
stories is supplemented with a section for ”grown ups” that describe a simple
game or exercise relating to the
story and focusing on
developing a different ability.
Throughout the
years I have seen these stories and games work wonders, which is why it’s important to me to make
them accessible to as many children as possible and the reason why all my
material will always be available to download for FREE (Check it out at youngherotales.com)Three of these stories are already out there on the web and have
been downloaded by hundreds of people for FREE.  I’m asking for your help to create the next story.“Kato and The Karate Master” will focus on dealing with peer
pressure. Through my research and experience I have
found that too many programs focus on how to deal with bullies but not on
preventing the underlying
cause that produces this
negative behavior. So many young children are influenced by the notion that
respect is linked to violence. It’s time we started breaking that link. The
game supplemented to the story is called “Follow me” and teaches listening
skills and respecting each other’s
personal space as well as learning about your own.Writing, Illustrating, editing and publishing the stories online in an e-book format
accessible to anyone takes me around 3 weeks of full time work, which is why I’m asking for your support so I
can dedicate the
necessary time

for this project.Let's Help Children!Any money you can contribute is greatly appreciated and if you can't contribute you can always share this campaign. column3: >GOALS – Girls’ Outdoor Adventure in Leadership and Science – is a free summer science program for high school students to learn science hands-on while backpacking through Sequoia National Park. In a two-week immersive program led by UC Davis and National Park scientists, GOALS scholars learn how to design and conduct field-based scientific experiments while developing leadership and outdoor skills.
column4: >We believe in the power of young people as leaders, scientists, and outdoors persons. GOALS is an opportunity for people who have had that experience of walking into a classroom, a lab, or an outdoor space and finding that no one else looked like them. We particularly encourage people of color, trans, nonbinary, genderqueer, and LGBTQ+ people to get involved with GOALS: this is for you!
column5: >The first GOALS program was in 2018 and we couldn't have done it without your support! We're gearing up for another successful year and we need your help to keep this program 100% FREE for our scholars.
column8: >GOALS seeks to cultivate and embolden the next generation of STEM leaders through a free, immersive, field-based summer science program for high school girls. The program uses an inclusive definition of ‘girls’ and welcomes all trans*, cis, genderqueer, and non-binary youth who may identify with girlhood.
column9: >We embolden and empower our students to participate in STEM careers and environmental stewardship by teaching a culturally sustaining, place-based curriculum. Scholars experience and co-create hands-on lessons that integrate science, outdoors skills, and leadership skills all while tapping into their natural curiosity and problem-solving abilities.
column12: >The GOALS program includes a two-week, immersive backpacking component as well as a year-long one-on-one mentoring component.
column13: >The immersive program involves a combination of hiking, front country (access to a car) and backcountry camping, and staying in dorms at UC Davis. During two five-day backcountry excursions, participants engage in hands-on learning and will complete small scientific investigations of their own. Their trek culminates in the completion of a scientific experiment of each participant’s own design, which they present on the last day.
column14: >All GOALS scholars are paired with a UC Davis mentor, who will serve as a mentor before and after the immersive summer program. Mentor-mentee pairs will meet informally throughout the year following, as well as attend follow-up events to help prepare participants for college applications and expose them to a variety of STEM careers and female STEM role models.
column16: >Learn More About Our Partners:
column17: >Sequoia and Kings Canyon National Parks
column18: >John Muir Institute of the Environment
column20: >Other Ways You Can Help:
column22: >Make sure to follow us on Facebook, Instagram, and Twitter!
column25: >We are currently building our size-inclusive gear library to outfit GOALS scholars for years to come and are in need of new or gently used gear donations. Contact us at goals.ucdavis at gmail dot com to coordinate your donation!
column28: >Applications are currently being accepted for many positions and are posted on our website!
column29: >Trip Leaders: deadline passed on February 22nd
column33: >Join us at Dunloe Brewing on April 5th!
column34: >Come support diversity in STEM and the outdoors (and perhaps enjoy a few beers while you're at it)! We'll be at Dunloe Brewing in Davis, California on April 5th from 4pm-8pm - a percentage of all proceeds will go to GOALS. We will also have a raffle of outdoor gear and local merch. More info: https://www.facebook.com/events/408097016591601/
column35:
> 

","About Us! GOALS – Girls’ Outdoor Adventure in Leadership and Science – is a free summer science program for high school students to learn science hands-on while backpacking through Sequoia National Park. In a two-week immersive program led by UC Davis and National Park scientists, GOALS scholars learn how to design and conduct field-based scientific experiments while developing leadership and outdoor skills. We believe in the power of young people as leaders, scientists, and outdoors persons. GOALS is an opportunity for people who have had that experience of walking into a classroom, a lab, or an outdoor space and finding that no one else looked like them. We particularly encourage people of color, trans, nonbinary, genderqueer, and LGBTQ+ people to get involved with GOALS: this is for you!The first GOALS program was in 2018 and we couldn't have done it without your support! We're gearing up for another successful year and we need your help to keep this program 100% FREE for our scholars. Learn more: https://girlsoutdoorscience.com​ Our Mission:GOALS seeks to cultivate and embolden the next generation of STEM leaders through a free, immersive, field-based summer science program for high school girls. The program uses an inclusive definition of ‘girls’ and welcomes all trans*, cis, genderqueer, and non-binary youth who may identify with girlhood.We embolden and empower our students to participate in STEM careers and environmental stewardship by teaching a culturally sustaining, place-based curriculum. Scholars experience and co-create hands-on lessons that integrate science, outdoors skills, and leadership skills all while tapping into their natural curiosity and problem-solving abilities. The GOALS Program:The GOALS program includes a two-week, immersive backpacking component as well as a year-long one-on-one mentoring component. The immersive program involves a combination of hiking, front country (access to a car) and backcountry camping, and staying in dorms at UC Davis. During two five-day backcountry excursions, participants engage in hands-on learning and will complete small scientific investigations of their own. Their trek culminates in the completion of a scientific experiment of each participant’s own design, which they present on the last day. All GOALS scholars are paired with a UC Davis mentor, who will serve as a mentor before and after the immersive summer program. Mentor-mentee pairs will meet informally throughout the year following, as well as attend follow-up events to help prepare participants for college applications and expose them to a variety of STEM careers and female STEM role models. Learn More About Our Partners:Sequoia and Kings Canyon National ParksJohn Muir Institute of the Environment Other Ways You Can Help:Spread the word! Make sure to follow us on Facebook, Instagram, and Twitter!  Donate Gear! We are currently building our size-inclusive gear library to outfit GOALS scholars for years to come and are in need of new or gently used gear donations. Contact us at goals.ucdavis at gmail dot com to coordinate your donation!  Get Involved!Applications are currently being accepted for many positions and are posted on our website! Trip Leaders: deadline passed on February 22ndMentors: March 15thScholars: March 29th Join us at Dunloe Brewing on April 5th!Come support diversity in STEM and the outdoors (and perhaps enjoy a few beers while you're at it)! We'll be at Dunloe Brewing in Davis, California on April 5th from 4pm-8pm - a percentage of all proceeds will go to GOALS. We will also have a raffle of outdoor gear and local merch. More info: https://www.facebook.com/events/408097016591601/",0.0,0,"3 Campaigns

<span style=""letter-spacing: 0px

...but not quite. Thanks to a generous group of friends, family, and inspired supporters, we've raised enough money to pay for materials and most other on-the-ground expenses. 

But we can't run a program without staff. That's where we come in. We're Nadia, Rebecca, and Christian. Having worked on developing the curriculum, and arranging logistics and all of the little details, we know the project best. We'll go to Bamako as mentors, instructors, friends, and behind-the-scenes-people-who-make-things-happen. 

With the help of Mohamed Kante, Mohamed Sankare and teachers from École du Progres, we'll be doing our best to teach and supervise participants, and examine the curriculum as we move forward to ensure its efficacy and further refine it. 

With your help the three of us will be able to go to Bamako for the pilot project.

We're so close, let's bring it the rest of the way!

Project Summary
We are members of iNERDE, a registered non-profit organization based in
Boston, MA that aims to empower children in West Africa by sparking their
interest in STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics) education,<span> because we believe science education is one of the
most important pillars of development for any nation.
This summer, we will be hosting a pilot project in Bamako, Mali. We hope to
foster a positive attitude toward the STEM fields through a six-week summer

camp for thirty 4th and 5th grade students. 

The camp will be divided up into modules including engineering, ecology, sustainability, space, and leadership and entrepreneurship.  It will teach children the importance of STEM values such as teamwork, problem solving, and technological innovation, which will enable them to recognize and solve existing and emerging problems within their communities.

Our pilot project is just the beginning of the
implementation of this vision. The future of Mali, and of Africa as a

whole, depends on the education of its children. 


The Impact
Studies conducted by the National Science Foundation
show that by the 4th grade, 33% of children in Mali, West Africa, express
negative attitudes towards the sciences, increasing to 50% by the 8th grade. In
a region with a pressing need for scientific and technological development,

educational opportunities for elementary children must be enriched.

Beginning this summer with our pilot program in Bamako, Mali, iNERDE is starting a paradigm shift in how STEM education is approached in West Africa. We'll provide our participants with access to a transformational science education that they otherwise wouldn't have. With this, they'll have the foundations to engage with science knowledgeably and critically, and to pursue careers in STEM.


The iNERDE Team 

Our team is composed of engineers, scientists, economists, and university students from Burkina Faso, Canada, Mali, Togo and the USA. Between us we have over 10 years of experience in educational development, community service, and the design and running of summer camps and after school programs around the world.

Our Long Term Vision

This summer's pilot program in Bamako will be the first time that the complete curriculum will be taught to a single group of participants. For the duration of the camp we will be evaluating the progress and level of engagement of each participant, and the efficacy of the curriculum as a whole. Upon completion, we'll review the program as a whole and incorporate the lessons we've learned into an updated curriculum which will be made available to schools across Mali and West Africa.


Other Ways You Can Help

If you aren’t able to help financially, we would truly appreciate if you could help us spread the word on social media and among your friends. You can do this by joining our conversations on Twitter and Facebook.

Between us we have over 10 years of experience in educational development, community service, and the design and running of summer camps and after school programs around the world.Our Long Term VisionThis summer's pilot program in Bamako will be the first time that the complete curriculum will be taught to a single group of participants. For the duration of the camp we will be evaluating the progress and level of engagement of each participant, and the efficacy of the curriculum as a whole. Upon completion, we'll review the program as a whole and incorporate the lessons we've learned into an updated curriculum which will be made available to schools across Mali and West Africa.Other Ways You Can HelpIf you aren’t able to help financially, we would truly appreciate if you could help us spread the word on social media and among your friends. You can do this by joining our conversations on Twitter and Facebook.",4.0,0,"1 Campaign
|","Montreal, Canada",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/science-education-in-mali/pica

A Strong Beginning, A Small Misfortune.
I am a sophomore at Berklee College of Music in Boston,
Massachusetts.<span>  I was admitted as a
Jimmy Lyons Scholar, receiving a full tuition paid scholarship in the fall of 2012.  The scholarship is awarded to one student for

the West Coast each year who gets to perform at the Monterey Jazz Festival. I played Monterey in September, 2012.

 In high school, I auditioned and was selected for the Young
Musicians Program at the University of California, Berkeley, where I
studied with world class drummer/percussionist, composer, producer, Ndugu
Chancler and the world renowned, multi-Grammy nominee, pianist, composer,
producer, international recording artist, Patrice Rushen.
I also auditioned for and was selected to be
one of the San Francisco Jazz High School Youth All Stars under the direction
of Paul Contos, which won second place at the 2012 Monterey Next Generation
Jazz Festival.

I am happy I was able to secure a scholarship to offset my educational expenses, as my mom is retired and my father passed away when I was twelve years old.  I was given my computer as a gift and my mom purchased the software. 

My misfortune occurred in October of 2013 when I sat my backpack down to greet a friend I had not seen on campus.  Seconds later, my backpack was gone.  I managed to complete the semester by spending late hours in the computer labs, making manual notations and borrowing time on friend's computers when they slept.  I was able to complete the successfully enough.  One of my professors could not tolerate the fact that I did not have a computer and advised me to drop his class.

Here is a breakdown of what I need and what I'm offering in appreciation for your contribution.
<li>In order to replace my laptop, I need $4000.  The laptop is a 15-inch: 2.3GHz with Retina display. Specifications include:<ul>
<li>
2.3GHz quad-core Intel Core i7
<li>
Turbo Boost up to 3.5GHz
<li>
16GB 1600MHz memory
<li>
512GB PCIe-based flash storage <sup>1</sup>
<li>
Intel Iris Pro Graphics
<li>

NVIDIA GeForce GT 750M
with 2GB GDDR5 memory
<li>
Built-in battery (8 hours)<sup>2</sup>
<ul><li>
<span>
The software programs are valued at: $1,500.
<li>For those who make a contribution, I'd like to offer event tickets in
column2: online drum lessons for aspiring drummers
column4: all as indicated in the perk section below.

column1: • If I do not reach my goal through this campaign, I will work to make the difference. It may mean that I will drop classes. I will do what I can to raise money to meet my goal.

The Impact

From 2008-2012, I was senior drummer for the Frederick Douglass Youth Ensemble at Oakland Public Conservatory of Music, where I was granted $1000 by ""Bread for the Journey"" a non-profit organization to implement a mentor-ship program that brought local legendary musicians together with local youth. I was able to impact the lives of both youth and elders and the community as they created music together.  I will continue to promote access to opportunities to develop talent and make positive change in communities with limited resources in music education.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot make a financial contribution, please help me get the word out about my campaign.  You can use the Indiegogo share tools to spread the word!

Who We Are

Urban STEM Academy is a community organization in Savannah, Ga and our goal is to introduce young children to programming and engineering. We do this by creating project-based learning opportunities for children in the community. Our goal is to introduce more urban children to STEM related fields and help them build the skills required for success in the workforce.

This particular campaign will help fund a weekend program where students will build their own computers using Raspberry Pi, an inexpensive yet powerful computer. By building their own machines, children will get a better understanding of what a computer actually is and they get to see first-hand how software and hardware interact. Our goal is that when we are finished, students will not only leave with their own computer, but they will leave with enough information and training to start creating their own websites and programs with their new machines.

What We Need 

So we have already had some wonderful people in our community donate monitors, keyboards, etc. Now, all we need to do is raise enough money to purchase the Raspberry Pi kits. The kits are $80 and include

  • Raspberry Pi and SD card

• Wifi Dongle and Raspberry Pi Enclosure
  • HDMI cable
• Powers Source

• Assembly Guide

    • The Impact

    Your contribution will help us change the lives of 10 children by introducing them to some of the highest paying skills in our country. Imagine it. We introduce them to coding , help them create their own projects, and then in the end they get their own computer to take home and continue pursuing their new found hobby.

Your contribution also helps us crank up a movement in our local community. There are very few places in our local community where children can learn how to code. By helping us make this happen, we are showing that programs like this can be successful and are supported by the community.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute, help us spread the word.

  • Share our campaign on your social media page
  • Tell your friends or anyone who may be interested

• Visit our website www.urbnstem.com and sign up for our newsletter to keep up with new events. There will be more.

Qui sommes nous ?
<blockquote>
<strong>
Neuf étudiants Français du Nord Pas de Calais, avec la volonté commune de réaliser des missions de solidarité internationale.
Notre association créée, nous avons eu envie de partager notre première aventure avec la population Péruvienne.
Dès Avril 2014, nous avons créé notre association  Psychomob'ILS, afin de pouvoir encadrer notre projet administrativement.
Notre nom est la contraction du mot Psychomotricité et de Mobilité, tout en mettant en valeur ILS, un clin d’œil aux personnes avec lesquelles nous agirons main dans la main.
Quatre des membres du groupe sont en effet spécialisées en psychomotricité, et pourront donc mettre à profit leurs compétences  au Pérou.
Quatre autres sont formés en informatique et technologies, ce qui peut être très bénéfique pour l'apprentissage de l'outil et pour réparer des équipements usés.
Un dernier membre est quant à elle formée en droit, et dispose de compétences humaines développées dans diverses expériences en animation.
Cinq membres de notre équipe sont par ailleurs qualifiés du Brevet d'Aptitude aux Fonctions d'Animateur (BAFA) et n'en sont pas à leur première expérience avec des jeunes.
Les valeurs qui nous animent :
<blockquote>
Aider…
Ne jamais cesser de voir que grâce à nos actions conjuguées, les enfants en difficulté peuvent se raccrocher la vie.
Échanger et partager…
s’enrichir des idées et influences de chacun.
Soutenir…
Donner simplement le meilleur de nous même, chacun à sa mesure, à sa guise, selon ses disponibilités, ses compétences, au gré
des aléas de la vie personnelle de chacun.
Vivre…
Tisser des liens, ici et là bas.
Agir...
Préférer les actions aux mots.
Nous avons lié notre projet avec l'association  Ayud'Art association Française basée à Nancy,
qui parraine le CIMA ou «Centro de Integración de Menores con Amor» au Pérou, à Cineguilla dans la grande banlieue de Lima.
Ayud'Art, le cadre partenaire de notre projet au CIMA
<a href=""http://www.hogarcima.org/"" rel=""noopener nofollow"" style=""margin-right: 20px
<a href=""http://ayudart.org/WordPress3/"" rel=""noopener nofollow"" title=""Enfants des rues du Pérou"">
Après de nombreuses lettres envoyées dans différentes associations au Pérou qui pourraient correspondre à notre projet de Solidarité,
l’association Ayud’art nous répond favorablement et les quelques échanges de mails ainsi que les longues discussions téléphoniques nous montrent la compatibilité
des deux projets. Ces discussions ont été déterminantes dans notre choix de prendre l’association Ayud’Art comme partenaire.
Ayud’art est une association Française, basée à Nancy. Elle a établit un partenariat en 2002 avec le Centre d’Intégration des Mineurs en Abandons (CIMA) installé
à 20 km de Lima dans la grande banlieue du Pérou. Des enfants de 8 à 18 ans sont accueillis au CIMA afin d’avoir de meilleures conditions de vie.
Ainsi ils apprennent à vivre ensemble, ils bénéficient d’un enseignement scolaire, sportif et culturel. Les jeunes sont répartis en pavillon selon leur âge,
la vie en collectivité est un maître mot. Le CIMA est pour ces enfants un deuxième départ dans la vie, ainsi ils ont demandé à changer le sens de l’acronyme CIMA,
le A signifie maintenant « Amour ».
Ayud’art nous aide à monter nos projets en lien avec la psychomotricité, l’informatique et l’anglais en nous guidant sur les différents besoins du centre
et des enfants sur place pour que nos objectifs soient en adéquation avec eux.
Nous prendrons la route en juillet 2015 pour un mois de vie commune, d'échange de culture et de connaissances, amenant chacun de nous à grandir par cette expérience de vie.
Les 5 axes de notre projet :
<blockquote>
La psychomotricité
pour permettre aux jeunes de comprendre le fonctionnement de leur corps.
L'informatique
pour sensibiliser les jeunes aux outils de communication et d'information et initier les enfants à leur utilisation.
L'animation
pour développer des temps d'échanges avec les enfants.
L'enseignement
pour valoriser les compétences des enfants en intervenant lors des séances pédagogiques de façon ludique.
la vie quotidienne
pour accompagner les jeunes dans les tâches qui les incombent (cuisines, travail aux champs, aide à la rénovation...).
L'échange
pour que les échanges s'effectuent dans les deux sens, ils vont nous apporter plus qu'on ne le pense.
Comment sera pérennisé le projet ?
Pour pouvoir pérenniser nos échanges avec nos partenaires, nous continuerons, lors de notre retour en France, à faire des actions pour collecter des fonds afin de les envoyer au CIMA.
Nous organiserons, entre autre, des évènements afin de faire connaître l’association péruvienne et ainsi sensibiliser la population autour de cette cause.
Nous voulons partager notre expérience, et encourager d’autres porteurs de projets de Solidarité à venir en aide au CIMA.
De plus, notre association Psychomob’Ils, sera amenée éventuellement, à partir de nouveau au Pérou en fonction de leurs besoins et des différents
constats que nous aurons pu faire sur place. Il n'est donc pas impossible de voir un nouveau projet de notre part, certainement plus précis sur les objectifs mais avec autant d'abnégation et d'envie.
A quoi va servir le financement?
L'argent récolté nous permettra d'acheter sur place, faisant fonctionner l'économie locale:
- une imprimante, des cartouches et du papier pour compléter le matériel de leur salle informatique.
-de la peinture, des pinceaux pour réaliser une fresque géante sur un des murs du centre.
- des filets pour aider la professeur d'hydroponie à restaurer son matériel pour la culture des salades en hors sol
- des manuels d'anglais pour aider les enfants dans leurs apprentissages.
Nous suivre :
<span style=""float: left
<a href=""http://psychomobils.wordpress.com/"" rel=""noopener nofollow"">
http://psychomobils.wordpress.com/
<span style=""float: left
L'équipe :
<span style=""float: left

Good day to you, Internet!

As the video says, my name is Robert Kroll. I am a part-time English professor at St. Clair County Community College, Jackson College, and Macomb Community College (yes, I teach at all three presently).

Recently, I decided that I should try to see if I have anything I could present at academic conferences. I submitted to a couple that caught my interest and a rather high profile one that I didn't think I'd have a chance for. Who knew that the three would accept me?
The conferences are:
Stage the Future II @ Arizona State University (March 7 to 8)- For this, I will be presenting a paper on the Doctor Who Proms of 2008, 2010, and 2013.

Orson Welles: A Centennial Celebration and Symposium @ Indiana University (April 30 to May 3) - Here I will be presenting a paper about the commercial and voiceover work Orson Welles did later in his life.
Great Writing 2015 @ Imperial College London (June 20 to 21) - I will be presenting a paper about the creative writing techniques of prisoners.

I am excited for all of these, but the most important one is easily the Great Writing 2015 conference, as that is at one of the world's most prestigious colleges and it will be for an international audience. There is also the possibility that the essays I present will be published in the future.

Sadly though, even with all of the work I have as an instructor, I do not have money to make it to all of these. I am saving as much as I can for these. I have money set aside already, but it is not nearly what I would like it to be. Additionally, I am applying for funds to go to these events, but institutional funding is never a sure thing.

The money you contribute will be going toward transportation (cars, public transit, airplane tickets and fees), lodging at each of the conferences (I'm not going for 5 star hotels. Days Inn and Airbnb are just fine by me), conference registrations, food at each location, and any other costs that arise from staying at any of these places.

I will assure you that while I will be taking in sights at all of these places, I am *not* doing this because I want you to fund my vacations. These are big opportunities for me and I am focused on giving the best presentations that I can.

In the interest of full disclosure, should I not be able to raise funds for everything, I will most likely cancel the ASU visit and all funds will go toward attending the Indiana University and Imperial College conferences.

By donating you will be helping me get to some major conferences, each of which have very important people who will be in attendance. Ultimately, I am hoping attendance to these will mean that I will enhance my portfolio and get a job as a full-time English professor somewhere.
Thank you for your time and consideration.

Short Summary

Evan's Destination Imagination Team from Bigfork Middle School competed in the State Championships in March.  They took FIRST PLACE.  Now, they are headed to the University of Tennessee (Go Vols) in May to compete in the Global Finals.  Their event...Tension Build.  At the state level, their 80 gram structure help 322.5 LBS (more than any other in history according to one of the appraisers/judges at the event).   

What We Need &
column2:
What You Get

All funds will go directly toward airfare, travel, lodging, food and registration for Evan and Charlie (Chaperon).  

The Impact

This event has been in the making for quite some time.  Evan was in his element at the state competition and we had so much fun together as father and son.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some of you just can’t contribute, but that doesn't mean you can’t help:

column1: • Help us get the word out and make some noise about this campaign.
• feel free to use the Indiegogo share tools on this campaign

And that’s all there is to it.

Thanks for your help.  Big Orange Country...here we come!!!!!!!

Thank you so much for everyone’s generous contributions

to PAX and helping us raise $55,419! 

We are so grateful for your help and support!!

___________________________________________________________________

Hi, I’m Alison Armstrong. If you are already familiar with our work, then you already know how important it is! If not, then keep reading because I will explain more below! And we have a gift for you just for considering our request.

Either way, I need your help. We have always run our organization on a shoestring. We keep our costs low so that as many people as possible can benefit from our work. But now we are up to something big, and it is going to take some money to get it up and running. The payoff will be that we will be able to reach the entire world
column2: dramatically leveraging our ability to affect the world, end unnecessary suffering, and embark on an era of human spirit and partnership. Please contribute to this effort financially if you can
column3:
every contribution builds momentum and energy toward taking our work global!

If you need to understand more about our work in order to make your decision, there is plenty of information out there! You may have heard me on the radio. Or seen me on TV. Or listened to a recording of mine on iTunes or YouTube. Or perhaps read the material or listened to these interviews on our website. We have a big commitment -- altering the culture of our world one human and one community at a time, by transforming the way men and women relate to themselves and each other. We do this by enabling people to see the instinctive sources of misunderstanding and discord between men and women, and then providing them with a new model of partnership that works not only in their personal world but also in every other area of their lives including work, family, community, and the planet. It is truly transforming.

I started PAX in 1995 with my dear friend Joan McClain, whose belief in the power of what I had discovered inspired me to share my discoveries. Since then we've opened the eyes and hearts of over 23,000 women in the Celebrating Men, Satisfying Women workshop, many on scholarship. And over 2,000 men have learned to see women in a new light, as courageous beings with minds, emotions, and perspectives that work in a way different from males. We have touched a lot of lives, and now it is time to take the work to a new level by reaching out across continents and cultures
to build a global community of humans working in partnership.

To make this happen, we need to move beyond our local workshop format and make the information available through Live Streaming, Webinars and a spectacular on-line community. Building this online capability takes more financial resources than we have, and that is why we are asking for your help.

Your generous contribution makes the following a reality:

column1: <ul>
• Development of a convenient, affordable online curriculum
• Live streaming of PAX workshops and webinars to living rooms and universities around the world

• Our online community membership site ~ ChoosingPartnership.com ~ where anyone ready to trade frustration for effective tools and empowering perspectives can Participate with like-minded and like-hearted men and women, Collaborate in new ways to apply our encyclopedia of understanding about men and women, and Investigate the frontiers of Partnership
• Promotion of ""The Queen's Code"" ~ the online book that transforms the way women relate to men and the way men understand themselves
• An elegant update to our website to provide more information and streamline navigation

In addition to knowing you are helping take this work to the world, we will express our appreciation for your contribution with a variety of exciting perks including the potential for privileged access to our global online community when it goes live. Many of them -- like our t-shirts and an intimate weekend with me -- are only available to donors
column2:
they're not for sale anywhere at any price!

Thank you in advance for your support. Every gesture of support is deeply appreciated by me and the other women and men committed to partnership. If there is a question you need answered to make this decision, please email me at Alison@understandmen.com.

Love, Alison

P.S. Also, please share this opportunity to make a difference with your
friends via email or social media: openingdoorstopartnership.com

P.P.S. I invite you to visit our website and connect with us:
- Website -understandmen.com
- Twitter - @PAXProgramsInc
- Facebook - facebook.com/understandmen
- Pinterest - pinterest.com/understandmen

Check out the ""Free Stuff"" page on the PAX website for videos, audios and more!

column1:
P.S.  If possible, please use PayPal for your contributions.

Thank you for considering our request!  Click here for your free gift:
alisonunplugged.com/thankyou.html
