Stepping outside of the Washington DC area, I'll be able to connect with youth and teachers in places like New York, Philadelphia, North Carolina. Out-of-state workshops and performances tend to leave a larger impact on young audiences. There's an added sense of mystery and mystique when youth are introduced to a presenter (or ANYTHING for that matter) that came from a place where they've never been. That in itself becomes a point of interest during the workshop. The phrase ""taking me places I've never been!"" begins to really resonate during out-of-state engagements. We'll also be able to add beautiful custom made t-shirts to the list of goodies to share!

At $30,000 we're fully fit to start reaching youth nationally with CDs, stickers, t-shirts, posters and MORE on a literal ""path of enlightenment"", shedding light and knowledge of positivity the entire time! Reaching youth in places which may have never encountered true Hip-Hop, then eventually returning to Washington, DC where my very existence will shine as a beacon of success to the numerous youth who are likely to have never left the District of Columbia. What better way to inspire them to value their education? What better way to show them the value of social skills and critical thinking? There are so many other things that must be accounted for, so I was sure to leave some of the budget to cover those things. Gas must be purchased. Tolls must be paid, and the list goes on and on.

I must stress again that this level of youth advocacy deserves far more than the ""minimum!"" This tour will change COUNTLESS lives. Anyone who experiences it directly will talk about it for years to come, I promise. My goal, however, is to leave an impression that lasts a LIFETIME. The age old question stands: ""If a tree falls in a forest and no one is around to hear it, does it make a sound?"" We want those who aren't there to experience the journey! We would love to document as much of the journey as possible. We'd love to share the vision with students and music lovers in other countries. Quality cinematic equipment is FAR from inexpensive, and to maintain the average person's standard of video quality we'd expect to spend $1500+ on the camera alone. That doesn't include feeding and housing the camera man for the duration of this bi-coastal journey. The trip itself will take anywhere between 1-2 months to run its full course and anyone who travels knows just how costly living on the road can be. It's absolutely vital that we keep in mind that the unexpected can (and quite often WILL) happen. A flat tire or ANYTHING of that nature can throw off plans severely when working with such an exact budget that lacks a cushion or room for adjustments. Nobody plans a trip to a foreign place with EXACT CHANGE. This should be no different.Currently we do not have ANY guaranteed press outlets or publicity agents. As a result, after reaching the $30,000 goal we will invest a small amount in different forms of advertising and press coverage to ensure that the world knows what's happening! To remove any concern you may have about the funds raised being used efficiently, one of my team members, a financial analyst, will work with me to manage the use of all funds raised. A financial report will be available for campaign supporters upon request.No matter the challenge, we can do this! ""It takes a nation to raise a village"". In 2012, the population of Washington DC was 632,323. Even with just $1 donations that's more than TWENTY times what we need. We can do this. No sweat.

The PerksThe motivation behind visiting schools and working with students should ALWAYS be to give THEM something, to leave THEM with new knowledge, to empower. That goes for any kind of educator, every subject, any theory. The prime beneficiary of this campaign will be the youth we meet along the way! The more we raise, the more we can do for the kids we'll work with! We've taken time to think of ways contributors can leave their own personal mark on history while helping a great cause AND snagging some priceless rewards in the process. It's a Win x Win situation!The biggest thing to remember is that we want to leave the kids something to hold on to. As a kid, how could you forget when there are stickers from the workshop on everybody's stuff? How could you forget when you have a beautiful painting hanging in your school's main hallway? We'll make sure that the kids never forget how the positive Hip-Hop made them feel. If we can get the entire school talking about positive Hip-Hop the kids will begin holding each other accountable!The ImpactI've come to realize that most people think that change won't happen unless it's something that BILLIONS of people join together to do... That is NOT true for popular culture. With popular culture, the most dynamic changes start with just ONE person doing something small yet noticeable. Everybody has influences, everybody has somebody they looked up to. Right now the youth want to be like the rappers they see on mainstream TV/radio... But there aren't any positive rappers in that mainstream arena. Nobody positive is creating what they seek while retaining a constructive perspective. WHEN this tour succeeds we will set a new example, and even if just ONE child decides to start being positive as a result, the cycle will begin to break. This list of organizations I've worked with grows constantly, and I strive to leave an open line of communication with the youth I meet via social networks. I've realized the kids only emulate what works. They need a reason to be positive. If they have someone who's not ""cool"" and or not ""successful"" telling them that they should be positive, they will turn away. They need someone who will show them the benefits of a positive outlook. When people have a positive outlook, they're more receptive to instruction, easier to connect with and more likely to be patient enough to process new information. Using positive Hip-Hop, we can bridge the gap between teachers and students, parents and children, the future leaders and the current leaders. I'm already doing it. Let's take it nationwide! Going Against the GrainHistory has always (in its own strange way) rewarded those who travel off the beaten path. My story has been no different.  I may not be world famous or have my music spinning on the radio daily... but when I show up at the schools, and those kids smile... When I hear them cheer, when they unite and clap in unison... When teachers have to drag them out of the presentation room because they refuse to leave before they get the autograph or picture that they've waited so diligently for... That's when I remember it's worth it. That's when I know it's working. The best part about my plan is that I've already done all the leg work. If you Google me, plenty material will pop up. I've worked with INCREDIBLE musicians and artists - some known nationally, others known internationally, some approaching global status. No matter the song subject, no matter who I collaborate with, my contribution will always contain substance and remain curse-free, setting an example for my young fans!The only risk I face with this plan is the possibility that the news of the campaign may not spread to the public. I admit, problems arise whenever I discuss expanding the movement, simply because people don't see the TRUE value in positive Hip-Hop. People are reluctant to help because they don't understand how Youth Popular Culture affects them. People don't take the movement seriously until they witness it first-hand. Teachers, parents, even government officials are often skeptical because this method is foreign to them... they've forgotten that in the beginning, somebody was able to bond with them through something that they were interested in at the time. They underestimate the power and reach Hip-Hop has... a culture that started in the slums of New York City which has now has spawned B-Boys, Emcees and DJ's worldwide recreating what happened when it all started.Ironically, I get around these obstacles by doing more and more youth work. I overcome these challenges by making more songs and attending more community events. I make connections constantly, and doors open. I'm incredibly diligent. It will work.Tell a FriendEveryone assumes that they need some sort of extravagant or elaborate plan when it comes to spreading the word. We're all guilty of it... Start with your CLOSE FRIENDS and FAMILY. Even if you grandmother, aunt or uncle can't support, they just might tell somebody else who will. Have you ever noticed how when you're telling a close friend about something you're passionate about, you never have to ""think"" about the method of explaining it? Sometimes it just comes out as a jumbled pile of words mixed with smiles and laughter... THAT is more convincing than a 60-second spiel will ever be when talking to close friends and family... because your friends know that if it's something that YOU'RE passionate about, then maybe THEY should be excited about it, too. Good energy is contagious. My music is changing the lives of people who hear it everywhere. Be encouraged!Share this campaign via email. Talk about this movement at work. Post this on facebook. Tweet the progress on twitter! Tell anybody you know who has kids, tell their teachers, tell your mentors, role models and advisers... The world needs to know. Be sure to use the IndieGoGo share tools!THANK YOU ALL SO VERY MUCH. We're changing the world. LITTLE, By little.",4.0,0,"1 Campaign
|","DC, United States",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/the-one-million-strong-tour/pica

#30Days of ThanksgivingLO  

You may not know this about me, but I had the AMAZING opportunity to go through a program called Legal Outreach in high school. Legal Outreach works with students from underserved neighborhoods around NYC and prepares them to succeed in high school, college, and beyond.  

I'm fundraising this November to make it possible for more students like me to go through Legal Outreach.  

My Story  

My name is Katherine Nuñez and I grew up in Bushwick, Brooklyn. I went to Beacon High School. 

My parents always did their best to make sure I went to a good school, and that meant traveling for over an hour so that I could go to school in Manhattan. I remember being the first kid in school, the security officer would open the doors extra early so that my mom could get to work on time. As I got older I wanted to make sure that the sacrifices my parents made would not go to waste. I was lucky, very few students who live in my neighborhood have had the opportunity to study outside of the neighborhood. I am proud of where I am from, but I am also grateful for the opportunities that have allowed me to move and grow beyond Bushwick. 

Alongside the support of my family, it was Legal Outreach that provided me with those opportunities. I know that if it weren't for the guidance and support of the Legal Outreach community I could not be where I am today. I owe them my success. 

Because of Legal Outreach, I was encouraged to apply to colleges and attended Williams College and made the Dean's List. LO supported me beginning in 8th grade, and I left LO four years later inspired and equipped for college. 

Your support can change the lives of more students like me!

Your Support Will... 

Make it possible for more students like me to go through Legal Outreach for four years of free programming, including a debate program, SAT prep, writing classes, mentoring, college application workshops, and much more! 

Of the students LO supports:
• 100% graduated HS on time (only 66% of NYC public school students do)
• 99% went on to colleges and universities
Other Ways You Can Help
• Donate to my campaign before December 2nd, 2014
• Share my campaign on social media
• Encourage your networks to support my campaign

I'm thankful for LO and I'm thankful for your support!  

#30DaysofThanksgivingLO
www.legaloutreach.org
www.facebook.com/legaloutreach
@legaloutreach

New York Cares Needs Your Help

New York Cares' Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math (STEM) programs pair volunteers with low-income, high-need elementary and middle school students. Our volunteers provide individualized support to the students who improve their math and problem solving skills, and boost overall classroom performance.

As part of our STEM program, we offer robotics projects at New York City public
schools. Your financial support will allow students to design, build, and program their own LEGO robots.

Donate today so students in high-need,
under-resourced public elementary and middle schools in New York City may be motivated to continue their studies in math or science, making a brighter future for us all.
About Children’s Education Programs
Through our many children's education programs, volunteers work with kids not only in schools but also in homeless
shelters, hospitals, and low-income housing projects. What remains constant, across all programming, is that our volunteers connect with children in need of positive
role models, and help provide opportunities that many of them would never have otherwise.
Your Donation
New York Cares' unique ability to leverage the time and
talents of tens of thousands of volunteers enables us to deliver six times the
value of every dollar donated. All the funds raised through this campaign will
go directly to our programs.
One Round-Trip Airline Ticket!
Everyone who makes a donation of $100 or more will be automatically entered into a raffle to receive one round-trip ticket within the U.S. and Canada on Delta Air Lines*!
*Exclusions apply.
About New York Cares
New York Cares was founded by a group of friends,
who wanted to take action against serious social issues that faced our city in
the late 1980s. Finding few options to help, they created their own
organization to address the problems from the ground up. New York Cares is now
the city's largest volunteer management organization, running volunteer programs
for 1,300 nonprofits, city agencies, and public schools.
More than 62,000 people volunteered with us this year because they know
they make a real difference. Together, we helped 400,000 disadvantaged New
Yorkers.

0,"<div class=""routerContentStory-storyBody"" data-v-1df7bf5a="""">For those that don’t know me, my name is Christina.  Launch day – September 10 – is my 29th birthday.  All I would like for my
birthday is to be able to put myself one step closer toward a long-time dream
of mine: becoming a nutritionist and wellbeing coach. So, here's my story:
I've always loved to help people in general – however I
could. Yet I never considered nutrition when I was younger.  I educated myself as much as possible on
herbs and essential oils.  This came from
my own problems with pharmaceutical drugs growing up. I thought I was fairly
healthy – I mean I was ‘skinny’ minus some typical woman fluff on my legs.  But then I started going to the gym when I
was about 22-23 years old. I really started to get a taste of the healthy
lifestyle and learned more and more about it.
Over the next 7 years, I learned much more. In learning and trying
different theories and thoughts, I've experimented with supplements, like
Herbalife, been a gym rat, and came full circle to just training regularly
(basic HIIT and calisthenics) with occasional gym time, and clean eating.
Through all of my self-teaching, I've gained the trust of
many friends and family members, each coming to me with their story and hoping
maybe I would have some information and suggestions to help them with their
health goals.  It’s not all weight
and fitness.  Among my friends and family
I’m known for being fairly positive and maintaining a clear, level-head even in
my worst of times.  All of them have
suggested I find some program or course for becoming a life coach or similar.
Then one day, a few months back a friend sent me a link to a course – he didn't
know I was looking even, simply said ‘I think this is something you’d be
interested in.’ And boy was he right!
Took me a little time to slow down and really look through
the website, but once I did I requested information instantly.  I received the information, even attended a
little online seminar to gather more information – this was it!  Talked to my family and they all agreed that
this was just what I needed.  Then I got
the price. Ouch.  I mean, it’s a great
price for what’s offered, but totally not in my realm of living right now.  But I didn't want to take no as an answer, so
I started brainstorming.  That’s
where we are today.
This campaign is my attempt to raise most of the funds
needed for tuition. But it’s not just about the course, it’s about having the
means to serve my community and help as many in the world to live a healthy
lifestyle that fits them – not a one-size-fits-all concept so many try and become
disappointed with. All I’ve ever wanted to do was help and this allows me the
avenue to do just that.
With your contributions, and my ability to start and finish
this 12 month course, you’re not only helping me achieve a personal dream, but
to give the means to comfortably and confidently reach out to help others with
a proper education and to support my ambition and drive that are hard to extinguish.
Know that your contributions will not only affect my life directly but also
indirectly affect hundreds, hopefully thousands.  I thank you in advance for your time and
consideration ofmy cause. I’m forever grateful from the bottom of my heart.
What I need and what YOU get out of this
Everyone loves to give – especially me.  Considering you’re giving to me, I’d love
to give to you more than I can express. While I don’t have a ton of things to

offer as a sincere thank you, I can and will offer various discounts on wellness programs and consultations once I complete the 6-month training course and receive my certification.  (Through the 12 month program, I will receive a pre-certification at 6 months so I'm able to work – kind of like clinicals to a med student.)  Also, I will
send personally handwritten thank-you notes on beautiful postcards from
Croatia, where I currently live.
I’ve set the goal here at $5,500USD.  My tuition is just a little over $6,000,
actually, but it includes everything from fees, books, an iPad mini to help with my school work, access to mobile applications to help stay on top of

assignments, and many beautiful perks like having all the documentation needed to get business going, a fully built website, and a few others.  It’s an incredible situation.  I’m not asking for all of it because I
just need most of it to get me started.  If I can reach the $5,500 goal, that’s
obviously a bulk of the tuition, and the rest I’ll cover through payments.  Even if the full $5,500 isn’t reached,
whatever is will go towards my tuition, so I may complete my first step towards
my goal of helping people.
At the 6-month mark, I’ll be able to give you your perks
that involve discounts on programs and consultations.  Posts cards will arrive in
November after the campaign is over.
Changing the World one person at a time
To elaborate a bit, your contribution is
not just putting me through school.  Rather, you’re helping me live a dream of giving
to and serving the world around us.  If there’s one thing I’ve learned about myself
these last few years, it’s that this is my calling.  Not only do I see myself in
the role of a helper/caretaker, but so do many others that know me.  They have encouraged me to take such a route
before I even gave it serious thought.  The
lack of a healthy lifestyle affects so many millions today all around the
world.  Societies worldwide need real
guidance of how to better balance life so that we can enjoy the gift of living,
not just drag our feet from one point to another in life, loathing it all and
being miserable.  No matter what our
backgrounds or current lifestyles, we all deserve to be happy.  My dream is to help people find their ""Happy,"" and your contributions will help me do that.
I’ve already managed to help a handful of people with no means
to truly serve them outside of personal experience and Google. I look forward
to the thousands more I can help upon completion of the course with your help.
<h3>Risks &amp
Some might be asking, ‘How do you plan to do all this?’ Or
maybe even something along the lines of ‘How are you so sure you’ll
finish?’  If there’s one thing I can say
about myself, it is that I don’t quit if I want it.
And I want it.  Yes, I work. But my type of work has a very flexible
schedule and my days are not 8-hour days. I will always have time -- or make time -- for my
assignments.  About 5 years ago, I was working
one 9-to-5 style job, and then a bar job Wednesday through Sunday at night,
working on my bachelors online, and going through an online certification
course to teach English as a foreign language.
I did it all
column2: I passed all tests and all assignments were above the

column1: standards.  My work never lacked either.
It’s just who I am.  So do not
fear that money will be wasted or that I’ll flunk out because my lifestyle is too
busy or crazy.  This course will be completed.
Other Ways You Can Help
I know
not everyone can help financially.
However, any noise you can make helps more than you realize.  There is a Facebook page you can follow.  There is Twitter.  I have a blog I’ve always used as a
platform to discuss healthy lifestyles that is also the launching point
for Mission Nutrition.  Sharing any of

these formats with your friends and families is greatly appreciated.  Links are below.

Again, thank you from the bottom of my heart.

course to teach English as a foreign language.

column2: I passed all tests and all assignments were above the

column1: standards.  My work never lacked either.
It’s just who I am.  So do not
fear that money will be wasted or that I’ll flunk out because my lifestyle is too
busy or crazy.  This course will be completed.
Other Ways You Can Help
I know
not everyone can help financially.
However, any noise you can make helps more than you realize.  There is a Facebook page you can follow.  There is Twitter.  I have a blog I’ve always used as a
platform to discuss healthy lifestyles that is also the launching point
for Mission Nutrition.  Sharing any of
these formats with your friends and families is greatly appreciated.  Links are below.Again, thank you from the bottom of my heart.",0.0,0,"1 Campaign
|","Memphis, United States",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/mission-nutrition--3/pica
0,"<div class=""routerContentStory-storyBody"" data-v-1df7bf5a=""""><div align=""justify""><blockquote><h1><span style=""color: 000000
column9: >Please join me to provide EVIDENCE-BASED, MEASURABLE ONLINE LITERACY PROGRAMS, and together we can offer ALL of our children a real shot at academic success.

column2: >Being a whistleblower is not good enough. It doesn't solve the problem. My name is Mary Willingham. I'm a learning and reading specialist. I worked in athletics at the University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill. And I blew the whistle on academic fraud in college sports. Many college revenue athletes are not getting the educational opportunity that we promise. One of the reasons: many of the young men we cheer for on game day are under-prepared for college level work.

>The system of college sport is perpetuating educational inequality and exploiting our young men. They are athletes who do not get paid and students who are not getting an education. Join me in sending a message to the leaders at the NCAA, universities, and in Washington DC, that this game of charades must end. Billions of dollars are being made off the backs of our college athletes and in exchange they deserve a real academic opportunity.

column1: With your support, we can fix this problem.
PCRead and a team of experts will develop an appropriate curriculum that delivers intensive reading instruction virtually.

The athletes with whom I  worked  wanted to learn. They were excited at the possibility of graduating with a degree in the field of their choice. Instead we kept them eligible by using, in the UNC case, a bogus paper class system of athletic eligibility where little to no learning took place. 98% of all college athletes 'go pro' in something other than their sport. Let's work together to make sure that after the last whistle blows, our celebrated athletes have a real chance at the game of life:
WHAT YOU WILL GET FOR YOUR SUPPORT:
What will my
donation be used for?
Paper Class Inc. has filed for 501c3 status. We will put together a team of experts and buy the platform and software necessary to train,
deliver, monitor (pre- and post-testing) and create the PCRead program--at no cost to
students. Our modest goal of $45,000 will allow PCI the start up money necessary to pilot the program in January 2015.
When will you
send me my pencil/whistle or tshirt?
They
will be sent out within 30 days after the campaign.
Who will have
access to the program?
The PCRead literacy program will call on middle school, high school and
community coaches who are already making a difference in the lives of students.
How will the
students get access?
Students
will register as a participant through their athletic program/school or community
organization.
When will the
program begin?
We
would like to pilot the program with athletes beginning January 2015. We are preapared to move forward and have been in conversations with the experts at  Ruzuku, Ace Reader and Lexia Learning.
How can I track
progress of the students participating in PCRead?
Paperclassinc.com
will be updated monthly to report and reflect on the progress of the program
and its pupils.
What can I do
help?
Donations make
this program possible. Please contact the coaches in your community and tell
them about the program. Connect them to the website at paperclassinc.com –
PCRead. Another way for you to help is to contact your congressperson, senator and/or
the Secretary of Education to underscore the importance of NCAA reform and a
real education for athletes.
<blockquote><blockquote>
Special thanks for permission to use clips from Schooled: The Price of College Sports.  Statistics referenced:
National Assessment of Educational Progress.
Inequalities in NCAA DI College Sports.
","Please join me to provide EVIDENCE-BASED, MEASURABLE ONLINE LITERACY PROGRAMS, and together we can offer ALL of our children a real shot at academic success.

Being a whistleblower is not good enough. It doesn't solve the problem. My name is Mary Willingham. I'm a learning and reading specialist. I worked in athletics at the University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill. And I blew the whistle on academic fraud in college sports. Many college revenue athletes are not getting the educational opportunity that we promise. One of the reasons: many of the young men we cheer for on game day are under-prepared for college level work.

The system of college sport is perpetuating educational inequality and exploiting our young men. They are athletes who do not get paid and students who are not getting an education. Join me in sending a message to the leaders at the NCAA, universities, and in Washington DC, that this game of charades must end. Billions of dollars are being made off the backs of our college athletes and in exchange they deserve a real academic opportunity.
With your support, we can fix this problem.
PCRead and a team of experts will develop an appropriate curriculum that delivers intensive reading instruction virtually.

The athletes with whom I  worked  wanted to learn. They were excited at the possibility of graduating with a degree in the field of their choice. Instead we kept them eligible by using, in the UNC case, a bogus paper class system of athletic eligibility where little to no learning took place. 98% of all college athletes 'go pro' in something other than their sport. Let's work together to make sure that after the last whistle blows, our celebrated athletes have a real chance at the game of life: LITERACY BEFORE LEGACY.
WHAT YOU WILL GET FOR YOUR SUPPORT:
FAQ’s:
What will my
donation be used for?
Paper Class Inc. has filed for 501c3 status. We will put together a team of experts and buy the platform and software necessary to train,
deliver, monitor (pre- and post-testing) and create the PCRead program--at no cost to
students. Our modest goal of $45,000 will allow PCI the start up money necessary to pilot the program in January 2015.
When will you
send me my pencil/whistle or tshirt?
They
will be sent out within 30 days after the campaign.

access to the program?
The PCRead literacy program will call on middle school, high school and
community coaches who are already making a difference in the lives of students.
How will the
students get access?
Students
will register as a participant through their athletic program/school or community
organization.
When will the
program begin?
We
would like to pilot the program with athletes beginning January 2015. We are preapared to move forward and have been in conversations with the experts at  Ruzuku, Ace Reader and Lexia Learning.
How can I track
progress of the students participating in PCRead?
Paperclassinc.com
will be updated monthly to report and reflect on the progress of the program
and its pupils.
What can I do
help?
Donations make
this program possible. Please contact the coaches in your community and tell
them about the program. Connect them to the website at paperclassinc.com –
PCRead. Another way for you to help is to contact your congressperson, senator and/or
the Secretary of Education to underscore the importance of NCAA reform and a
real education for athletes.

Short Summary

Raising money through this campaign will help me reach my goal of becoming a Chiropractor and will ultimately help me pay for school and other various expenses that it takes to make it through stress-free!
• My name is Jon-Marc Ream and I am a recent graduate of Indiana Wesleyan University with an Bachelor of Science in Exercise Science

• This campaign is so important to me because it allows me to not only go to school and reach my dream, but also help me focus more on my education and less on working so much to balance out paying for school.
• 10% of my earnings will be donated to the organization I choose and ultimately the charity that I see being the most beneficial in the health realm.

The Impact

My passion in life is to help people become healthier. I've realized that our world is becoming more susceptible to unhealthy habits through various types of decisions. My start is through Chiropractic School and becoming what I've longed to do!
• Helping people function and live a healthier life is my essential goal
• Allowing others to benefit from the gift of life in all aspects that they can
Other Ways You Can Help
• Any  kinds of gift cards for places to eat or even things to shop for while I'm living will be so beneficial
• Contact me through email with any other ways you can think of helping!
• Email : indwes24@gmail.com

0,"<div class=""routerContentStory-storyBody"" data-v-1df7bf5a=""""><div> <h3>Hello!
We are a group of
undergraduate and graduate students working with 20 amazing kids at an afterschool program in South Tucson.  On May 1<sup>st</sup>, we will be taking them
on an overnight fieldtrip to the University of Arizona to enjoy team-building recreation and games!  This would be an amazing opportunity

to introduce students to a college campus, while they experience new activities and bond with their peers.  But we need your help to raise funds so every child can attend. Any amount is greatly appreciated, but please consider a donation of $35.00 to pay for a child's admission for the field trip.
The city of South
Tucson has a rich cultural legacy and strong community values.  However, there is a much higher proportion of
families living in poverty in comparison to Pima County and the US.  Thus, many families lack the resources to

connect their children with experiential learning beyond the classroom.  It is our hope to provide the kids with a memorable night at the University of Arizona to excite them about post-secondary education.
Thank you for your contribution!

<span style=""font-size: 30px

In response to the current crisisin Nepal, International Drikung Kagyu Council (IDKC) in Nepal have set up a team called ""IDKC Nepal Earthquake Reconstruction Committee"", comprising 11 representatives, who are monks and lay devotees. 


We are Drikung Kagyu devotees in Beijing, China. Due to the communication barriers in Kathmandu, we decided to help raising funds and updating the info.
All

the donations will be sent to  ""IDKC Nepal Earthquake Reconstruction Committee"" bank account.

In the aftermath of the massive earthquake that struck Nepal on 25 April, Their society members, while being enmeshed in the struggle for survival themselves, are helping others to overcome the predicament they are in, and at the same time, trying to grasp the scale of the damage. There are currently several areas that are in urgent need of relief funds.

The monks from Rinchen ling  Monastery sent food to victims.

To help the victims in Mamdi village.

They are followers of Tibetan Buddhism, who have for generations called Nepal their home. They know their people and their way of life. As a Buddhist group, they actively manifest their compassion and sense of unity in helping one another.

A List of Work-in-Progress:

1) Emergency provision of relief items like tents, tarpaulin, basic food stuffs, medicine, clothing, sleepingbags etc, to the earthquake victims, who live in the vicinity of the Nepal branch members’ community as well as those in remote areas.

2) Counseling for those affected by the earthquake.

3) Providing assistance to orphanages and those elderly who live by themselves.

4) Renting of helicopters for the delivery of disaster relief items to those victims living in Lapchi mountains and Chosam area, which are now inaccessible by land due to road damage and the collapse of bridges, and also for assessing the condition in those areas in order to evacuate the injured to the hospitals in Kathmandu.

5) As some areas are experiencing internet and mobile communication ‘cut off’, we are now helping those foreigners who have gone on a pilgrimage tour to Lapchi by contacting their family members overseas and updating them on the situation.

To make a rescue plan in midnight.


To deliver the relief supplies to remote villages.

List of requirements  -

Short term needs:

Tarpaulin, tents, sleeping bags, blankets, clothing, medical supply, rental of trucks, cars and helicopters.

Volunteers and doctors needed.

Medium and long term needs :

Generators, solar panels, walkietalkie, satellite phones, reconstruction of bridges, roads and houses.

To provide medicines to the victims.

To guide experts inspect building damages.

One of the projects:

Lapchi Snow Mountain is situated in the eastern part of
Nepal on the border with Tibet, at a height of about 4850 meters. It is
considered to be a very holy place that has been blessed by the presence of
siddhas and masters like Mahasiddha Saraha, Padmasambhava and Milarepa who
meditated in the caves of Lapchi. Lapchi is closely bound up with the history
of the Drikung Kagyu. Kyobpa Jigten Sumgön had sent countless Vajrayana
practitioners there and in the centuries that followed many outstanding masters
from the Drikung lineage went to Lapchi to advance their practice. Many
practitioners went on extended meditation retreats in one of the numerous
sacred caves.
Main
road that connects Lapchi to Nepal destroyed.<div>
We have been notified by members of Lapchi association that
almost all of the homes in Lapchi have been destroyed along with roads,
bridges, monastery and retreat homes. A few of the people have also been
injured and they were brought down to Kathmandu to be admitted in the hospital.
Since
the roads were in bad condition, this photo was taken from helicopter showing
homes destroyed.
The people residing in Lapchi are poor and live in simple
homes made of stones and metal roofs. They lack the abundance of basic
utilities like electricity, heat, hot water and gas for cooking that we take so
for granted. With the recent earthquake the situation has only gotten worse. The
simple homes that they lived in have been destroyed and they have been left
homeless. Currently they are living in self-made shelters in nearby caves. Many
have lost all animal live stocks like yak and cows that they greatly depend on.
Due to the recent rain and the roads being completely
destroyed, the much needed aid has not reached them from the nearby cities.
Somehow till now the villagers have managed to survive due to the fact they are
used to living simple lives. But they are concerned about the future weather in
the next few months starting August, when it will start to snow in Lapchi. They
need to have their homes repaired before that.
A
few of the Lapchi pilgrims who were rescued by the Lapchi association.
Lapchi villagers and monks seeking shelter
in self-made temporary homes in nearby caves

0,"<div class=""routerContentStory-storyBody"" data-v-1df7bf5a=""""> <h1><span style=""color: rgb(0, 0, 0)
column6:
>Fund the quarterly air time costs for ""Let's Talk Native...""

My name is John Kane. I host two of the most important Native talk shows on radio. I am not a paid radio celebrity but rather an activist with a microphone. I am in my 5th year of my own show on WWKB 1520AM in Buffalo, NY. ""Let's Talk Native...with John Kane"" is a weekly two hour, live call-in show that features in studio guests ranging from community leaders to lawyers to Native entertainers and educators. The show is on commercial radio and those two hours per week are purchased blocks of time. WWKB is a powerful 50,000 watt station giving the station tremendous reach by radio and with our show streaming live and on-demand we reach the entire world. 

My work on LTN has also landed me as the interim host of ""First Voices Indigenous Radio"" on WBAI in New York City. FVIR has been a solid presence in the NYC market for over a decade. I was honored to be asked by its founder, producer and regular host Tiokasin Ghosthorse to fill in for him. WBAI is community supported radio and while this weekly one hour show does not require the purchase of airtime, I do cover my own travel and lodging.

This campaign, however, is specifically raising funds to cover the airtime for ""Let's Talk Native..."" With LTN as my home for important conversations rarely heard anywhere else, it has opened the door for me to appear on radio in Washington, DC
column8:
Minneapolis/St Paul and on internet radio like Blogtalk Radio and Native America Calling. My voice on this show has transform me into a go to resource not only for radio but as a public speaker and television appearances as well.

The airtime this fund drive will purchase keeps important conversations on Native issues in the mainstream media. Without shows like ""Let's Talk Native..."" there is no Native activism on radio. On LTN we deal with environment, climate, racism, sovereignty and spend significant hours of radio teaching our history, culture and even language. 

Please support this fund drive and keep the conversations going.

With the help of Frontier and Turners Falls High School
students, Amped for Education opened a learning center in August 2014 in
an impoverished area of Nicaragua. The area schools have dismal records
when it comes to test scores, attendance rates, and achievement.  The
idea behind the learning center is to communicate with public school
teachers and reinforce concepts that are learned in class through project-based
learning.
The need for education
in the community could not have been more profoundly demonstrated as
the center was broken in to and the learning materials for the children were
stolen. The chairs that our students sit in each day, the soccer balls
that they use during recreation time, and the food that they eat during
break were all taken. Our instructors used this as a learning moment to explain
to students that doubling down on their commitment to themselves through
education can prevent their generation from being so desperate. We have
now provided another job, albeit unexpected, to a Nicaraguan, as we
have a security guard at the facility overnight to ensure that nothing
like this happens again.
<i>The
students and community have shown great resolve during this, still
attending class the very day after the robbery
the chairs and taking turns standing during lessons. Community members
rallied around us and provided temporary supplies to repair our fence.
Now, we need your help to replace the items taken and help pay for the
caretaker that will help ensure security in the future. For example, one chair costs

approximately $6, but absolutely no donation is too small.  All of the money raised will go directly to supporting the learning center and the education of Nicaraguan students.

Can't make a donation right now?  No problem!  Share this fundraising campaign with friends and relatives and together we will show that anything is possible!

These are the students that should go to Yale University's Y-Hack

You've heard about the diversity problems in tech: incredibly low percentages of minorities in some of the best-paying jobs. According to PBS, only 6% of all tech workers are Hispanic.

In our computer science program, we're fortunate to change the trend. Within our cohort-based degree program, we have 90% Latino students and 85% first generation college students. We have a group of 6 students that were selected to compete at this years Y-Hacks out of several thousand applicants! They only obstacle in their way is the lack of travel funds. That's where you come in!

• I'm one of the 6 students in CSIT-In-3 , an intensive, accelerated Computer Science Bachelor's degree program at Hartnell College and CSU Monterey Bay
  • Y-Hacks is more than just another hackathon. It's a place to learn the latest technologies, network with other CS students, and learn about job opportunities from sponsors in Silicon Valley.
  • This is why attending Y-Hacks is so important for our group of students, who attend a small school and live in small cities or towns--places where the focus is on agriculture, not technology. Y-Hacks offers opportunities the students won't get anywhere else, and can jumpstart their careers in tech.
Fundraising details

• We have a total cost of $400 per student. That includes travel and food for the trip to Y-Hacks for a total of $2400. So with the fees that come with Indiegogo, we have set our goal at $2500.
  • Whether or not we reach our entire goal, the funds will go towards sending as many students as possible to Y-Hacks

Other Ways You Can Help

    We really appreciate everyone's enthusiasm about this project. If you can't donate, ask your friends if they would be interested. We know there's more than one software engineer out there with a bit of extra money looking for a good home. This is a incredibly direct way to help underrepresented students have a better future in technology, for themselves and for their families.

","These are the students that should go to Yale University's Y-Hack You've heard about the diversity problems in tech: incredibly low percentages of minorities in some of the best-paying jobs. According to PBS, only 6% of all tech workers are Hispanic.

In our computer science program, we're fortunate to change the trend. Within our cohort-based degree program, we have 90% Latino students and 85% first generation college students. We have a group of 6 students that were selected to compete at this years Y-Hacks out of several thousand applicants! They only obstacle in their way is the lack of travel funds. That's where you come in!

I'm one of the 6 students in CSIT-In-3 , an intensive, accelerated Computer Science Bachelor's degree program at Hartnell College and CSU Monterey Bay Y-Hacks is more than just another hackathon. It's a place to learn the latest technologies, network with other CS students, and learn about job opportunities from sponsors in Silicon Valley. This is why attending Y-Hacks is so important for our group of students, who attend a small school and live in small cities or towns--places where the focus is on agriculture, not technology. Y-Hacks offers opportunities the students won't get anywhere else, and can jumpstart their careers in tech.
Fundraising details

We have a total cost of $400 per student. That includes travel and food for the trip to Y-Hacks for a total of $2400. So with the fees that come with Indiegogo, we have set our goal at $2500. Whether or not we reach our entire goal, the funds will go towards sending as many students as possible to Y-Hacks

Other Ways You Can Help We really appreciate everyone's enthusiasm about this project. If you can't donate, ask your friends if they would be interested. We know there's more than one software engineer out there with a bit of extra money looking for a good home. This is a incredibly direct way to help underrepresented students have a better future in technology, for themselves and for their families.",0.0,0,"1 Campaign

THE PHILOSOPHER, THE MAGICIAN AND THE TRICKSTER

A holistic way or perceiving and acting in the world
We are four Schumacher College
alumni taking our learnings from Holistic Science and Economics for
Transition on a journey of sharing around Europe, May and June 2015. Our gift
is a series of experiential and co-creative workshops, offered with an open
heart and in service of sustainable living. Keeping at the core of our tour the
spirit of a pilgrim, the project will be funded through gift economy, inviting
individuals to contribute to the journey in whatever way they feel able and
moved to.
Inspired by the archetypal qualities of
the Trickster, the Philosopher and the Magician, we bring play, reflection and
transformation in a workshop format where participants are invited into a
learning community that shares the responsibility for sense-making.
Our intention is to connect
people and places working for a better world, in unique ways: an educational
centre in Austria (The Centre for Global Change and Sustainability), social activism hubs in Spain, a mindfulness community in France and permaculture
centers in Portugal are currently on our route. The offering is a
combination of whole person, experience-led thinking and seriously fun play - an
expanded vision of education. We will invite people on a journey that starts with perceiving the world anew and our relationships within it
more freely, and leads to joyful action for change.
We will explore with participants
topics such as the nature of perception (through a phenomenological approach),
moving towards a living kind of thinking (with Goethean Science), our
relationship with our ecological selves (with Deep Ecology and Gaia Theory),
the complexity of connections as part of living ecosystems (with chaos &amp
complexity theory), as well as practices of collaborative and common based economy and practical examples of community change from
across the world as an inspiration to co-create the human living systems we
desire.
To reach beyond physical presence at the workshops, we will share
our journey through a blog where we celebrate moments, tell stories of the
places and people we meet and reflect on the experience of learning with a
diversity of humans in different contexts. We will also share the tools—processes,
methodologies, games—that we discover or co-create through our work in an e-book that will be available online, for free to everyone.

column3:
>

To get to all the places we want to visit and to support ourselves, we need around £6000 (50% for transport, 40% for food and 10% for materials). We are crowdfunding for 2/3 of what we need.

column1: So that this dream can be inclusive and people can participate regardless of background or financial resources, we need your help. Contributing to this campaign you will join our team in opening windows of possibility across Europe.
Any help, thoughts,
ideas, connections, contributions or enthusiastic support - please get in touch
with us at pmtworkshops@gmail.com
Visit pmtworkshops.tumblr.com for updates on our journey and workshop venues and dates.
With joy and warmth,
from Daniel, Fernanda, Felipe and Joana
By the way, we are not offering formal perks, as everything we are doing is already about sharing, but please let us know if there is something you would like!

What Is YPMP?

The “Young Professionals Mentoring Program (YPMP)” is a non-profit youth mentoring organization dedicated to building lasting relationships between young professionals “mentors” and high school students “mentees”. Our goal is to enhance social development, provide positive role models, and give students a caring and supportive outlet. We believe that, through mentoring, we can help our student mentees set and reach their academic and personal goals. By contributing to our campaign you can provide highly-motivated, goal-oriented high school students with life-long mentors.
What Do We Need?

Our aim is to raise $8,000. All proceeds go directly to fund our events and the administrative costs associated with the program. This sole campaign will fund all of our events for the upcoming year. Additionally, we are a registered 501(c)(3) organization, so your donation is tax deductible.
All donations are welcome. However, there are perks for donations over certain amounts, which are noted to the right.
<div>
<div><span style=""background-color: initial
Anyone who donates over $25 will receive a bracelet for reduced drink prices at our celebratory happy hour on June 18th.
<div><span style=""background-color: initial
column2: >Finally, the mentor that raises the most money this year will win a prize for him/herself and his/her mentee.

column1: <div><span style=""background-color: initial
<div>
<span style=""background-color: initial
The Impact
<div>

YPMP partners with The High School of Economics and Finance (HSEF), a public high school with approximately 750 students from all five boroughs of New York City. HSEF is located in lower Manhattan at 100 Trinity Place. We are currently mentoring 58 students and are extremely proud to be working with such an impressive group of young people.
All YPMP mentors are trained by the New York City Board of Education and meet with their respective mentees at least once per month at YPMP organized events.

Having a positive role model is extremely valuable to high school students as they are deciding on important life choices such as choosing a college, a major, and ultimately a career path. Since most mentors are at an early stage in their careers, they can provide relevant advice on these decisions based on their experiences. Additionally, having exposure to the wider group of mentors gives  these students access to an excellent network of professionals to help them find internships and jobs once they graduate.

YPMP has sponsored and led a number of group activities for our mentors and mentees. During the course of the academic year we organize monthly group events. The goal of these activities is to introduce our mentees to the many cultural and educational opportunities that New York City has to offer, by experiencing them together, and to build a lasting friendship and bond between mentor and mentee.
Other Ways You Can Help
Just because you can't contribute money, doesn't mean you can't help! There are other ways to help the cause:
1) Join the cause - Join YPMP as a mentor (We are especially interested in mentors that want to take a leadership role within the program).

2) Internships - We are always looking for internships for our mentees in business, finance and accounting related fields. If you are looking for young, motivated students eager to enter the workforce and make an impact, reach out to us.
3) Information sessions - Our mentees love to learn about all types of businesses. If you are interested in hosting our group for an event, please let us know.
4) Spread the word - Help us by sharing this campaign with family and friends.
For general information or inquiries about YPMP, please contact our Directors:
Nick Cashan (nick.cashan@gmail.com)
Vic Punwani (vicpunwani@gmail.com)
If you are interested in becoming a mentor, please contact:
Adam Binford (radam.binford@gmail.com)
Dan Grayzel (dgrayzel@gmail.com)

Short Summary

My name is Tim Blewitt, and in October 2014 I ventured to Brussels, Belgium to attend the highly selective international theatre  program at L'ecole de Lassaad.  I attended this school for one year and improved my education on physical theatre, movement, anatomy, and improvisation by utilizing observations of the natural world to become a movement specialist in the most theatrical sense possible.

My campaign is to help me finish the second and final year of this  program so that I may have the opportunity to fully immerse myself in the entire curriculum of the Lassaad pedagogy.  Without the final year of this pedagogy, my education in this field will not be nearly as satisfying, and will always feel incomplete to me.  If you are able to contribute to my campaign, you will not only help me to finish one of my most passionate dreams of attending this school, but you will also enhance my education as a serious theatre practitioner.

What I Need &
column2:
What You Get

In order to pay the tuition of the first trimester, I need $2,000 dollars.  All of this money will go directly to The Lassaad School for tuition.

In return for your contribution, I will send you a picture of myself in the city of Brussels applying one of the many physical/theatrical elements that I have been learning at the school.

The Impact

As one of my teachers explained to me at the school, ""Everything we do in life is interesting.""  Every movement we make, every action we take, has a cause, a purpose, and an effect.  The education that I am receiving now has truly revolutionized the way that I look at human interaction, and the way that I behold the beauty of everyday life.  Your contribution will allow me to continue on this path of ever-improving my perspective of natural life, in addition to helping me specialize my continuously growing craft of theatre performance.


Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to contribute financially, I appreciate your taking the time to read about my campaign.  If I could ask you to take just a few minutes more to share this campaign with friends and family  --  anyone who might be able to help  --  it would make a world of difference to me.  Thank you so much, and I look forward to sharing my adventures with you!

Our Story

Having only learned how to hoop last year (at age 53), I have found the benefits include weight loss, lessens depression, helps stop/reverse arthritis and osteoporosis and I am hoping to share this amazing tool with the world. My goal is to donate hoops to schools, senior centers and homeless shelters to encourage everyone to have fun getting fit.

For my first goal, I would like to donate 30 adult sized hoops to Amelia Earhart Continuation School in North Hollywood. This school allows at-risk teens to complete their education and get their diploma, even if they have not had the best track record in school. There is no budget for actual P.E. classes so the teachers do their best to include some type of fitness activity during the day. With the budget cuts at all LAUSD schools there is no money for equipment so we would greatly appreciate your donations.

Many of these teens have no outlet for physical fitness activities and would greatly benefit from learning the varied moves of Hoop Dancing. This awesome ""new"" fitness craze utilizes music to get people moving and dancing, while working the core and strengthening the back muscles. Hooping can be a low impact cardio, burning 300 calories an hour or it can be worked up into a great aerobic exercise to burn up to 600 calories per hour. There's no actual skill or rules so anyone can hoop and have fun getting fit.
Please help fight the obesity epidemic in our country by helping me teach young people to find this fun exercise!

I am asking for $900, which will cover the time and materials for making 30 adult assorted sized hoops. If I don't receive all of the $900 I will make as many hoops as the funds will cover. If, for any reason, I receive more than the amount asked for I will apply it to my next project which is donating hoops to the kids of L.A. Family Housing
column2: a transitional shelter where I will be volunteering every week to teach the kids hooping. That's also my next IndieGoGo pitch

column1: Unfortunately, I don't have any perks to offer at this time... if you're in L.A. you could come to any of my hoop groups for free!
<div>
I would appreciate if you told anyone that you think would be interested about this project.
Hoopers - I need you too! Want to donate some time? There are hundreds of schools/shelters that could use you!

Hi there!

My name is Devon, and I'm a volunteer for a small non-profit organization called Koga International Development Association. Koga began in January 2011 as a small project that aimed to teach life skills to children in disadvantaged areas through swimming. Koga means to swim in Kinywarwanda, the local language of Rwanda which is the location of the first swimming project set to start August 2012.

The Swimming Project will take place in Kigali, the capital city of Rwanda. There are numerous hotel pools in Kigali, and the city is only a few hour's drive from both lake Muhazi and lake Kivu. There is very little access to swimming and water safety instruction in Rwanda which limits children of the region from gaining experience in and around water, a major source of work in the lake regions. Lake Kivu is one of Rwanda's largest import and export stations. By providing children with water safety knowledge and swimming skills they will gain greater opportunities for employment in the fishing industry, with boats, and even at hotel swimming pools.
There are four of us going over to Rwanda to teach swimming and water safety. We are all certified swim instructors and lifeguards with backgrounds in competitive swimming.

The organization's founder is over in Rwanda already teaching teachers to teach swimming. They will be shadowing us as we teach boys from a local orphanage between the ages of 4-22 for three weeks. We will continue to fund the project for at least 5 more years. We want our project to be as sustainable as possible and will make sure that the teachers have the resources they need to continue it!
By contributing to this campaign, you can help prevent drownings and help increase the opportunities for young people in Rwanda to gain employment in water-related fields.
What We Need &
The money we raise through this campaign is going directly to the project, all four volunteers are paying their own way over to Rwanda.
Here are our expenses:
$1300 = pool rental
$1700 = bus rental to transport the children
$1310 = accommodation for volunteers for 3 weeks
$1200 = food for volunteers for 3 weeks
$200 = translator
Total needed for project: $5710.
What we've raised so far: $1518
What we still need to raise: $4192.
To be realistic, I've only made our goal on this campaign $2,500 and will be holding other fundraising events in Vancouver, BC to raise the rest.
The Perks!
Besides feeling like an awesome human being for helping out with the project, you get some perks in appreciation for your help!
If you donate $25: you get a picture of a child who learned to swim with your help with a letter of appreciation.
If you donate $100: you get the previous perk, PLUS some traditional Rwandan embroidery. You will also be listed on our website as one of our donors!
If you donate $200: you get both the previous perks, plus a beautiful traditional woodwork art piece from Rwanda.
The Impact

By donating to this campaign, not only are you directly funding the Swimming Project, but you are also encouraging a very small non-profit to continue doing projects around the world in the future. This is our first one, and we are extremely excited to begin building up a foundation of knowledge and volunteers in order to improve on our projects in the future.
Other Ways You Can Help
If you can't donate yourself, you can still help the campaign by sharing this page on your facebook, twitter, blog, etc!
If you live in the Vancouver area, you can also help out by attending or volunteering at our fundraising concerts and events.

Thank you so much for taking the time to read this and for any support you might be able to give. We really appreciate it.

The organization's founder is over in Rwanda already teaching teachers to teach swimming. They will be shadowing us as we teach boys from a local orphanage between the ages of 4-22 for three weeks. We will continue to fund the project for at least 5 more years. We want our project to be as sustainable as possible and will make sure that the teachers have the resources they need to continue it!
By contributing to this campaign, you can help prevent drownings and help increase the opportunities for young people in Rwanda to gain employment in water-related fields.
What We Need & What You Get
The money we raise through this campaign is going directly to the project, all four volunteers are paying their own way over to Rwanda.
Here are our expenses:
$1300 = pool rental
$1700 = bus rental to transport the children
$1310 = accommodation for volunteers for 3 weeks
$1200 = food for volunteers for 3 weeks
$200 = translator
Total needed for project: $5710.
What we've raised so far: $1518
What we still need to raise: $4192.
To be realistic, I've only made our goal on this campaign $2,500 and will be holding other fundraising events in Vancouver, BC to raise the rest.
The Perks!
Besides feeling like an awesome human being for helping out with the project, you get some perks in appreciation for your help!
If you donate $25: you get a picture of a child who learned to swim with your help with a letter of appreciation.
If you donate $100: you get the previous perk, PLUS some traditional Rwandan embroidery. You will also be listed on our website as one of our donors!
If you donate $200: you get both the previous perks, plus a beautiful traditional woodwork art piece from Rwanda.
The Impact

By donating to this campaign, not only are you directly funding the Swimming Project, but you are also encouraging a very small non-profit to continue doing projects around the world in the future. This is our first one, and we are extremely excited to begin building up a foundation of knowledge and volunteers in order to improve on our projects in the future.
Other Ways You Can Help
If you can't donate yourself, you can still help the campaign by sharing this page on your facebook, twitter, blog, etc!
If you live in the Vancouver area, you can also help out by attending or volunteering at our fundraising concerts and events.
Thank you so much for taking the time to read this and for any support you might be able to give. We really appreciate it.",0.0,0,"2 Campaigns
|","Kigali, Rwanda",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/kida-teaching-swimming-and-water-safety-in-kigali-rwanda/pica

The Fulmore Middle School Girls Choir, from Austin, Texas, has been invited to sing at Carnegie Hall in New York. Fulmore was invited by Maestro Francisco Nunez, world renowned children's chorus director and founder of the Young Peoples Chorus of New York City.
We need your help. Fulmore is an economically diverse school and not all of the girls can afford to go. We are raising the funds to make sure all the girls can go. If everyone can't go, then no one goes. Thank you for your support!!!

Short Summary

PAVE Academy Charter School is a public elementary school in Red Hook, Brooklyn. Our first grade comprises of two classes of 25 adorable, smart, funny, and engaged 6 and 7 year olds. Our school mission is to ensure all of these students graduate elementary school on the academic path to college.

Christie, Cori, Jessica, and Nicki are the lucky teachers of these students. In efforts to provide these students with the best education possible, we would like to take them to the Metropolitan Museum of Art as a field trip this July. We need your help in raising funds for a bus to take them to and from the museum.
<div>
<h3>What We Need &amp

For the last Literacy unit of our term, we are going ""around the world in a glass slipper"" - students have the opportunity to read Cinderella Stories from around the world and compare and contrast the tales based on the origin cultures of the stories.

To truly understand the cultures from which our focus stories originate (China, Mexico, and Egypt), we would love to take our students on a field trip to the Metropolitan Museum of Art to compare and contrast the art in these regions.

This is where we need your help! The Board of Ed does not provide bussing in July (the date of our proposed field trip) and private buses are expensive. We would love to raise money for a private bus to take our kids to (and from!) the Met! Without a way to get there, we cannot go - but with your help our kids can gain so much cultural exposure and have what will undoubtably be one of our best field trips ever!
The Impact
<div>

This field trip will provide an invaulable kind of education our kids cannot receive in the classroom - they will gain exposure to classic pieces of art and a deeper understanding of world cultures. Your help in getting us to and from the museum will make this opportunity possible!

My name is Maria Almanza. I am a New Yorker, who is currently pursuing her education in nursing. I was visiting Nepal this summer for an independent study and to gain more hands on clinical practice. Originally my plan was to volunteer as a nurse at the hospital, College of Medical Sciences ,in Chitwan, Nepal... and come back home.

However, it turned into something much more than what I had expected. While I was doing my rounds, I noticed there were an immense amount of patients who needed hemodialysis due to kidney failure and also patients who had a plethora of cardiac diseases, and the reason being is DIABETES. Many of these medical problems could have been prevented by early diagnosis and health education. Unfourtunately, the people of Nepal can not afford reguar health exams, and therefore, many are living with DIABETES AND THEY DO NOT EVEN KNOW... UNTIL IT IS TOO LATE.

These patients do not have medical insurance in order to receive any type of health care. Patients literally have to sell their homes and all of their belongings just to get hemodialysis, treatment, which cost about 3,500 Rupees/week  ($43.00US). That does not include the cost of hospital stay, medication, lab work, food ,and other  needed resources  Patients need to pay for everything out of their pocket!  When I learned this, I knew I wanted to help. I set up a meeting with the Director of College of Medical Sciences, and told him about my desire to help. He informed me that chronic diseases are drastically rising in Nepal, and the government does not provide any help for the people.
With good fortune and help from the hospital I was volunteering at, I started a local Non Profit Organization in Nepal
column2: College of Medical Sciences Diabetic Foundation. There is a committee of doctors and nurses and well renowned community leaders, who are willing to volunteer their time and take me to the villages of Chitwan.  The goal is to provide free health care which includes: diabetic testing, administering medication, and educating  the local people about  nutrition and health issues. Many people live hours away from any hospital or health post, with no access to any form of transportation.  If patients need to go to a hospital or doctor, transportation will be provided by the foundation.

column1: College of Medical Sciences Diabetic Foundation will make an IMMENSE impact on the lives of the people of Nepal and can change the future of Nepal’s healthcare system.

How can you help? Donate! You can contact me directly through email with any questions you may have. There is no “middle man” here. All donations will go through me. I am returning back to Nepal in February to start my work. I will be in direct contact with the patients, doctors, nurses, pharmacists and medical suppliers. Your money will be directly forwarded to the sustainability of the foundation.
Here is a brief breakdown of where the funds will be going:
$10.00 will provide $70.00 worth of medical supplies such as wound dressing, linens and educational material
$25.00 will provide $175.00 worth of medical equipment such as stethoscopes and blood pressure machines.
$25.00 will provide insulin for 50 patients
$50.00 will purchase an exam bed
$75.00 will purchase a hospital bed
$100.00 will provide an insulin pump for 50 patients
$500.00 will establish a pharmacy
$1,500 will establish a community lab
$3,000 will establish the construction of a local clinic
If you would like to donate supplies rather than money, that is completely POSSIBLE!
If you can not make any kind of donation at the moment, please  spread the word!
Our future goal is to build a clinic equipped with exam rooms, a pharmacy, a fitness room and a yoga/ meditation center.
With the help of your donations we can make a huge impact on the needy people of Nepal. Please BE AWARE AND SHARE.

My Heart:

I spent last year in Hungary. I've been back in the U.S. for more than 6 months, but I can't stop thinking of two village communities that I fell in love with. I spent every Tuesday and Thursday afternoon attending church services and playing games with the children afterwards. Being able to help provide them with a safe place to play and be a kid brought me so much joy. I truly miss these beautiful people.

One day last year, I had the opportunity to take 4 girls from one of the villages to an adventure park. Although it as a 5 minute walk from their homes, they had never been there before. This was by far my favorite day in Hungary. I had so much fun with these girls. We couldn't communicate that well, but Annita (the youngest of the bunch) kept shouting the lyrics to the Flo Rida song ""Ohh, ohh, sometimes, I get a good feeling!"" Then she'd ask me, ""Good Feeling, Ms. Anna?"" That day she smiled more than I had ever seen before.
These families that I spent time with don't have much (no running water, small and often unsanitary living conditions) but they're gracious, loving, and resilient. I want to give back to them.
<div>
What We Need:

The money will go directly to the missionary family who planted the churches I attended along with 5 other churches. The parents names are Anna and Choi, and they have an 11-year-old daughter named Lidia. All of the funds given to them will be used to help the Roma churches this family cares for.
<ul>
• By raising 500+ we can help a village get running water.
• Money will be used to sponsor education for children. (Only one in four complete primary school)

• Money will be used to help feed children and motivate them to stay in school. The missionary family has two places in Romania (a border country) where Roma children can enjoy a free lunch. The only thing the children have to do is prove they attended school that day. The money we raise can help feed daily nutrious meals to these children and keep them in school.

-My prayer and dream is to be able to hand deliver the funds we raise and spend a week in Hungary playing sports and organizing fun activities for the kids this summer. This is a last priority though, and something we'd have to go WAY above and beyond to afford, but I'm putting it out there.
<div>
Additional Information:

This isn't a charity. This is a partnership, and that means we aren't giving and walking away. Anna and Choi (the missionary family) are there every day to guide and support the work that these people are doing. They are helping them find jobs, partnering and teaching these families to grow sweet potatoes and other crops, and helping them become independent.
If you type ""Roma in Hungary"" or ""Gypsies in Hungary"" into google, you'll find countless articles about the struggles this fundraiser is set up to combate.
<div>
Other Ways You Can Help
If you don't have the resources to help us at this time, but want to be part of our mission, you can do so by:
Using the Indiegogo share tools

Telling your friends and family

Baltimore TheatreWorks: Kids + Theatre = A Difference

Here’s what we know: Theatre enriches children’s lives. When students rehearse, they learn discipline and commitment. When students perform, they gain self-confidence and experience positive recognition, some maybe for the first time. When students watch plays, they understand the power of storytelling and realize that, in the end, what unites us is far greater than what separates us.

Here’s what else we know: In 2012, the Baltimore City Public School System has 14 full-time equivalent theater teachers – one teacher for every 8,000 kids. That equation doesn’t add up. That’s why I founded Baltimore TheatreWorks. I need your help to make a difference in the lives of thousands of children in Baltimore.
Here are some numbers that do add up.
What your support will make possible.

Colorism is a play I wrote about how the tone of someone's skin can make a huge difference in their lives. The play features 3 women – one light-skinned, one medium-skinned and one dark-skinned – and explores the cultural issues associated with that. We’ll tour city high schools and engage Baltimore’s best actor/teachers. Our student audiences will talk and write about the issues raised by the production, openly engaged in a way they’ve never been before. Cost: $50,000

The Teen Performance Program will provide area teens the opportunity to work with professional directors and designers, in three annual productions ranging from Shakespeare to August Wilson. As producer, I’ll promote the work of these talented kids throughout the region. Cost: $30,000 (3 plays @$10,000 each)

Baltimore TheatreWorks co-founder Joan Weber will train theatre artists who want to be theatre classroom teachers. Here’s some more bad math: When the school system tries this, the average teacher lasts one month. They don't know how to write lesson plans or manage classrooms, so they have no chance for success. We’ll train, support and place dedicated teaching artists in city schools, and we’ll keep supporting them once they start. Cost: $50,000

Baltimore TheatreWorks artists will direct and produce after-school theater productions in Baltimore City schools for students, family members and the community. There is no better way to bring a parent into the school than to put their kid on stage. Once the parent is in the building, there's no telling what kind of good relationships can be built. Cost: $5,000 per school

Act now so our kids can act now. Please help us make this work a reality. Become a Founding Donor today, or give at whatever level you can. Contact us at with your ideas or questions. Let’s imagine a day when Shakespeare’s famous line “All the world’s a stage” extends to the public schools and communities of Baltimore – changing lives, neighborhoods and ultimately a city.

column10: >My name is Benjamin James Williams and I was raised in the theater. For years I have seen plays, acted in them, and worked backstage. My family for years has worked in theater. This year, I am part of the high school premier of Tarzan. Tarzan is a great movie, it's hard to maneuver into a play but our program did it.  We performed in Kenosha, WI, at Bradford High School and now we will be traveling to the International Thespian Festival in Lincoln, NE. I've been in productions at Bradford, but this was my first time on crew. I run one of four follow spots. I've seen many students, past, present, and hopefully future who have the same goals of becoming successful actors and technicians. We have been taught by the best directors, technicians, and all around good people.
column19: >As far as the trip goes, it's only beneficial and well worth it. Not only is it plainly a fun time but it’s also not bad to have “being in an international festival’’ on your side for future college choices. Each child does need 800 dollars to go which isn't that easy to collect. The same people in this show are very hard working. We have been earning the money necessary to go but it’s important that we get a little boost. The cost includes everything for the week long festival. Busses, food, lodging at the dorms at UNL, classes during the day and tickets to see 8 productions over 7 days. I've also seen how much stress it can cause to the people who have to manage all of these things. Not only does it take all their effort to find a safe bus company and plan the production tour, managing the kids schedule can be stressful but the biggest factor is always money. This is a very big opportunity for us educationally. Many colleges will be there to meet prospective students. There are several ways you could be seen and promoted. But like I said before, we are very talented and enjoy what we do and we could really use some help.
column28: >I will be happy to share my trip with you by sending postcards and pictures from the festival. You should see what a great opportunity this can be for kids. You can also check out festival coverage and detailed schedules and information at www.edta.org

column1:
This campaign is being run by my mom, a theater teacher.
Please pass our cause along to friends and family who might help, and support your local educational theaters, wherever you are!
