column1: My Story

Hi, my name is Mashawnda Dowell. I go by Masha. For the past year I have been obsessively going to the Actors Space website at www.actors-space.org. I would go to the site and just day dream about attending the workshop. Well, I wrote down my vision, and I let it go. Well, last summer when I was let go from my lucrative job as a Quality Manager, I gave some more consideration to this educational opportunity, and then I forgot about it... AGAIN. Well, this past Spring I decided I would like to actually go. So, I signed up for email updates on the site and all, and I attempted to shape my personal finances to allow me to go. Well, as life would have it, my money was not adding up well to go. However, I still kept my dream of attending. Well, two weeks ago, the organization sent out an eblast telling people about their "" Fenix Award"". Its basically an award that goes to the best candidate to assist them with the fees associated with the program. WELL, as it turns out, I nervously submitted an essay for the opportunity and I got the AWARD!  Well. I am deeply grateful for the award, but now I need to raise the rest of the fees within 2 weeks.

I am a professionally trained scientist turned actress. I am from Winston-Salem, NC. My first play was in 7th grade, "" A MidSummer's Night Dream"". I attended Tri-Cities High School's Drama program for a year, and then I went back to regular public high school my 10th grade year. Between 10th grade to my college graduation I did not think of drama again. In 2000, I obtained a BS in Agriculture Science, and for almost a decade, I worked mostly graveyard shift as a scientific researcher, while I found my calling in arts and entertainment. My calling led me to LA to intern at several big name production companies, and to DC to study media studies at Howard University for a year. After DC, I returned to NC, and I decided at 30 years old to go after my dream of acting. In 2008, I was cast in a short play, in 2009, a full length play, and then in 2010 I obtained an agent, and starred in a commercial. In 2011, I have done the most to date: 1 commercial, 2 student films, 1 Indie film, and background work on 1 feature film and 1 TV show. I have a deep interest in world cinema, and I believe that my education at the Actors Space will be a catalyst to get me to my dream of being an international actress.
My personal website www.mashadowell.com
THE EDUCATION

The Actors Space is an organization in Vic, Spain that assists actors with their acting education. This can range from various techniques, to acting for the camera, and other helpful work. The thing that I find most attractive about the school is the fact that I, as an American, will get the opportunity to connect with people from all over the world. I will get to be exposed to performers like me, but from other countries --- who take their craft very seriously. In America, I have been professionally trained at the TVI Actors studio in Hollywood in TV Hosting, Scene study with famed acting coach Vera Katz, Scene study with popular actress Tasha Smith, and last but not least, I have been trained in improv at the Raleigh Little Theater. This summer, I want to add that I have been trained internationally at the Actors Space in Spain.
YOUR HELP

Of course I'm going to work my butt off to obtained the funds for the trip myself. I must go! This is a chance of a lifetime, however, I need additional financial help. If I could do it all myself, I'd jump for joy, but I can't. So, I am asking for your help.
PROJECT BREAKDOWN
Who: Masha Dowell
What: Study in Vic, Spain at Actors Space - Actors Space in Vic, Spain
Dates: August 3rd - 16th
Where: Vic, Spain ( A suburb of Barcelona)
How: God, Myself &
How Much: $2000
- Flight from Atlanta to Barcelona = $1400
- Travel transfers from Barcelona to Vic = $100
- Program = $500 ( w/ award discount)
a. Program includes lodging, meals

Vision

In partnership with Peace Conflict and Resolution, a grassroots organization in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), we are creating a community-driven action-plan. Our focus is centered upon trauma counselling training for women and adds capacity building for future projects focused on community wellness, sustainability and self-sufficiency.  It is our belief that we are all whole, capable and resilient people who, with necessary supports, can self-determine the healthy transformation of our communities.  We have been invited to join such work of communities in Bukavu.
The Impact

Your support of this self-sustaining training program will help local communities create better lives for the people in Bukavu.  Investing in this type of work gives support directly to the people most impacted by violence and poverty in the DRC. Our work is voluntary so that we can use our resources for implementing grassroots projects on the ground. However, we have to get there first.
Short Summary

Bukavu city is on the Eastern side of the DRC. The DRC has been under much political turmoil for years because of the resources in the area - gold, diamonds, and coltan are some of these. Because the resources are in such high demand there is no end in sight. For instance, 65% of the world's coltan is supplied by the DRC.  Coltan is used in most electronic devices, cell phones, computers, ink jet printers, camera lenses, etc.

Caught in the dynamics of war between multinational corporations (some of them Candadian companies), rebels and government—all fighting for land resources—the people in Bukavu, and other small villages, are under constant threat of violence, theft, and execution. These clashes directly affect women and children through displacement, rape, hunger and violence and leave them susceptible to forced conscription into rebel armies.
Basic survival needs, security, food and clean water are scarce resources and hard to supply to the many children who are orphaned and left to fend for themselves.
We have seen the devastation of Indigenous communities in our home territories in the North, and feel called to support other communities facing similar or worse conditions in the DRC.

Kim Haxton is joining forces with the DRC the Peace and Conflict Resolution, founded by Pastor Samuel Muderhwa and his wife Faida Muderhwa, to counter-act the throws of poverty and cycles of violence by offering local sustainable training programs to women and their families, to provide aid and hope to those in Bukavu.  Peace and Conflict Resolution (PCR) was founded in Bukavu,  South-Kivu by Pastor Samuel and Faida in 2004, to create peace and reconciliation, to bring broken families together, to give vulnerable children hope, and to encourage women who have been affected by the war.

PCR activities focus on education to nurture and promote responsible decision making and problem solving skills. PCR registered as a non-profit organization with the division of Justice and Human Rights in D.R.Congo in 2007. For more on their programs please visit

column1: Who we are
<div class=""WordSection1"">

Kim Haxton, HBOR, BA, is Potowatomi, is from Wasauksing First Nation. Kim has over 20 years of experience in direct community work.  Kim joined Dr. Beth Hedva, former Director of the Canadian Association for Trauma Outreach and Prevention, on four trips to Haiti after the 2010 earthquake to voluntarily support trauma counselling training.  Kim is dedicated to offering customized training programs on conflict resolution, de-escalation, diversity, and trauma recovery in support of women, children, their families and communities world-wide.

Pastor Samuel Muderhwa and his wife Faida Muderhwa offer aid to families in Bukavu through the organization Peace and Conflict Resolution.  Pastor Samuel and Faida both completed a diploma from the school of Mediation in Nairobi in 2006, this challenged them to continue to expand the vision of PCR. The people of Eastern D.R.Congo have passed through unimaginable chaos caused by the wars that have taken place in the region. PCR is a humanitarian organization and not a political one.
<div>
What We Need
1 plane tickets to Kigali,1 to/from Vancouver , 1 San Fransisco
1 plane tickets from Kigali to Cyangugu, Rwanda
visas Rwanda and Democratic Republic of Congo
20 stipends for participants
rental for teaching space
car and driver
accomodation and food
Money to support community-directed initiatives that follow our visit.

The Trip of a Lifetime
For years Shorewood High School's Special Education students have watched their peers load buses for spring break trips.  The Spanish club to
column2: >Guatemala, the band trip to Gettysburg, French club to Paris. Not fair! ""Why can't we go?""  So last spring, Best Buddies teacher Chris Gagne sprung into action - yes, why NOT us? So, off to a spring trip to environmental and life skills program in Hawaii we go!

column1: Best Buddies is a fabulous international organization dedicated to opening opportunities for friendships, jobs, and inclusion for folks with intellectual and developmental disabilities.  It emphasizes the development of social skills by peer partnering (the ""Buddies). It was started by Anthony Shriver, son of the founder of Special Olympics Eunice Kennedy Shriver.
BTW this portrait of Ms. Shriver was done by a Best Buddies parent.

Our ""Big Trip"" as we call it will be in April of 2014 and will not only be an opportunity to learn about bugs, lava, volcanoes and all that cool stuff, but also how to travel and interact with peers and the public:

Following a group itinerary (how to stay aware when part of a group?).  
Waiting in line (no skips, everyone's in the same boat). 
Sleeping in a strange bed with a roommate (how do you adjust to change?). 
Sticking close together (how to deal when you really just want to be alone).
Going through security (really, my WHOLE BODY?). 
Finding the last pair of clean underwear (keeping track of your stuff).  You know, life stuff.
What We Need &
We need to get 13 students and two teachers there and we need to cover costs for our AWESOME bugs/rocks/lava/seaweed program being run by Wilderness Inquiry.
Small and big amounts count!  The cost is $37,500 ($2500 per person).  We've got a little money in the bank, and the students have been working hard with local businesses local fundraisers

column3:
/>

and getting donations from aunts and uncles that show up on the Wilderness Inquiry Thermometer.   We're setting our Indiegogo goal for $28,500 (anything extra we'll save for next year's trip).  Think about just adding what you can to the (tax-deductible) pile:

column1:
Even if we do not reach our Indiegogo goal, all funds raised will still be used to cover student expenses as part of the trip. Check out our overall fund raising activities and progress towards goals on our Facebook page.

 

The Impact

For many of these special needs students, this is the only opportunity they'll have to travel with their peers and friends.  As they leave high school and enter the world of work, few of them will land in jobs or situations where they'll be able to travel.
<ul>
• The experience will allow students to learn important life long skills
• The trip will help foster students confidence and sense of independence
• And, other travelers along the way will be touched by the sense of joy and opportunity that will clearly be evident

Even if you can't contribute, help get the word out about the Best Buddies trip!

Share our itinerary and information about our trip with your family and friends!

","The Trip of a Lifetime

For years Shorewood High School's Special Education students have watched their peers load buses for spring break trips.  The Spanish club to Guatemala, the band trip to Gettysburg, French club to Paris. Not fair! ""Why can't we go?""  So last spring, Best Buddies teacher Chris Gagne sprung into action - yes, why NOT us? So, off to a spring trip to environmental and life skills program in Hawaii we go!
We hope.  With your help.

Best Buddies is a fabulous international organization dedicated to opening opportunities for friendships, jobs, and inclusion for folks with intellectual and developmental disabilities.  It emphasizes the development of social skills by peer partnering (the ""Buddies). It was started by Anthony Shriver, son of the founder of Special Olympics Eunice Kennedy Shriver.
BTW this portrait of Ms. Shriver was done by a Best Buddies parent.

Our ""Big Trip"" as we call it will be in April of 2014 and will not only be an opportunity to learn about bugs, lava, volcanoes and all that cool stuff, but also how to travel and interact with peers and the public:

Following a group itinerary (how to stay aware when part of a group?).   Waiting in line (no skips, everyone's in the same boat).  Sleeping in a strange bed with a roommate (how do you adjust to change?).  Sticking close together (how to deal when you really just want to be alone). Going through security (really, my WHOLE BODY?).  Finding the last pair of clean underwear (keeping track of your stuff).  You know, life stuff.
What We Need & What You Get
We need to get 13 students and two teachers there and we need to cover costs for our AWESOME bugs/rocks/lava/seaweed program being run by Wilderness Inquiry.
Small and big amounts count!  The cost is $37,500 ($2500 per person).  We've got a little money in the bank, and the students have been working hard with local businesses local fundraisers

and getting donations from aunts and uncles that show up on the Wilderness Inquiry Thermometer.   We're setting our Indiegogo goal for $28,500 (anything extra we'll save for next year's trip).  Think about just adding what you can to the (tax-deductible) pile:
$10 covers one student's science kit for the day ($150 covers everyone's)
$25 moves one around on the ground for a day
$50 puts lunch and dinner on the table
$75 buys three meals for a day
$100 gets a student a place to rest for the night
$250 buys EVERYONE morning juice, bagels and coffee
$500 gets a special student to Hawaii (and $500 brings them home!)

Even if we do not reach our Indiegogo goal, all funds raised will still be used to cover student expenses as part of the trip. Check out our overall fund raising activities and progress towards goals on our Facebook page. The Impact

For many of these special needs students, this is the only opportunity they'll have to travel with their peers and friends.  As they leave high school and enter the world of work, few of them will land in jobs or situations where they'll be able to travel.
The experience will allow students to learn important life long skills
The trip will help foster students confidence and sense of independence

About Us

As a statewide, dual-language immersion charter school in Georgia, the International Charter School of Atlanta (ICSAtlanta) will be available to all children in Kindergarten through 4th grade regardless of their county of residence. 

Our aim is to open our doors for the 2015-2016 academic school year as we have submitted our charter petition to the State Charter Schools Commission and hope to receive approval by fall 2014.  Our educational model will incorporate Georgia's education standard requirements (common core or otherwise) in the following languages: Mandarin, French, German or Spanish in combination with English. In order to help us better plan for our classes, please fill out an intent to apply form for your child(ren) at www.ICSAtlanta.org.

Over the last year and a half, our Board has worked diligently to bring this educational opportunity to our community. Please help lend your support by making a donation to help offset our start up costs during our pre-opening year.  Any amount, no matter how small, is greatly appreciated!

To stay up to date on our progress, please register to receive email updates by visiting our website at: www.ICSAtlanta.org.

Other Ways You Can Help
• Volunteer to help out at one of our restaurant fundraisers this spring and summer.  All you have to do is invite friends to eat with us at our designated restaurants!
• Sign up to play in our first annual ICSAtlanta Golf Classic on July 21, 2014 at Laurel Springs Golf Club. Cost is $100 per player or $350 per foursome
• Donate an item for our silent auction
• Like us on Facebook and use the Indiegogo share tools to encourage your friends to donate $10 or more
• Be sure to join the contact list on our website so you never miss an update!
• Find us at: www.ICSAtlanta.org

When was the last time you went to the bathroom?

Remember the last time you had to search for a bathroom when you weren't at home? Imagine if you felt that same frustration for your entire life.

5 million people in Ghana (19% of the population) are forced to relieve themselves in open fields due to lack of infrastructure and resources.  These people and many others around the world are denied the common right to security and comfort during such a necessary and private act.  More importantly, open fields of waste can and will negatively impact the health of any nearby community.  We're trying to change that.
<span style=""line-height: 1.45em
column2: >Pure Home Water (PHW) is a non-governmental organization (NGO) registered and based in Tamale, Ghana.
column3: >It was founded in 2005 by Susan Murcott, a Senior Lecturer at the Department of Civil and
column4: >Environmental Engineering at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT).  The organization
column5: >built a factory to manufacture its AfriClay Filters – a locally-sourced clay pot water filter – in
column6: >Taha, a village adjacent to Tamale. While the current focus of work is in household treatment for

column3: >After speaking with local villages, it became clear that improved sanitation was a priority but was inaccessible due to lack of resources and high costs.  In addition, many people lack an understanding of the relationship between improved sanitation and their health.  So, how can we help?
column5: >We decided to start with the children.  Children will be making decisions in the future and will also influence their parents now.  In June 2013, PHW built a 6-stall toilet block in 30 days for a school in the village of Taha.  Since this project was so successful, we decided to keep the momentum going!  We are planning to build the same toilet block for the neighboring village of Gbalahi.  Why give?
column7: >Your contribution not only allows for the construction of the proposed toilet block, but also employs local workers from Gbalahi and the surrounding villages.  Your contribution ensures the the children of this village will be better protected from disease and will begin educating the children and their parents on safe hygiene practices.  Ultimately, your contribution will change lives.
column13:
What You Get

Our costs primarily include the labor and material costs for the toilet block, monitoring to ensure sustainability, travel and living expenses for one graduate student to oversee the construction, and some small miscellaneous expenses.  All funds will be directed towards this project and if excess funds are received, we will begin planning additional toilet blocks for surrounding villages!  A detailed breakdown of costs is available as an image in the gallery for your reference on this page.

What will you get?

We have four levels of incentives for giving.

column1: <li><span style=""line-height: 1.45em
column2: >If you give $20, we will be forever thankful and your name will be included in the list of contributors.

column1: <li><span style=""line-height: 1.45em

column1: <li><span style=""line-height: 1.45em

column1:
Who will this help?

This toilet block will serve 200 primary school children and influence many others as well.  Not only will this project keep the children and teachers safe and healthy, but will begin to educate on better sanitation practices, keeping future children safe and healthy as well.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you're unable to contribute, please pass this along to your friends and family that may be interested.  This is a very important and time-sensitive problem that can be addressed!  We encourage you to research the problem to better understand it's global significance and see how you can help make important change happen!

Pure Home Water in the News: http://web.mit.edu/newsoffice/2013/long-haul-to-bring-clean-water-to-developing-nations-1210.html

","When was the last time you went to the bathroom?Remember the last time you had to search for a bathroom when you weren't at home? Imagine if you felt that same frustration for your entire life.5 million people in Ghana (19% of the population) are forced to relieve themselves in open fields due to lack of infrastructure and resources.  These people and many others around the world are denied the common right to security and comfort during such a necessary and private act.  More importantly, open fields of waste can and will negatively impact the health of any nearby community.  We're trying to change that.

Pure Home Water (PHW) is a non-governmental organization (NGO) registered and based in Tamale, Ghana.  It was founded in 2005 by Susan Murcott, a Senior Lecturer at the Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT).  The organization built a factory to manufacture its AfriClay Filters – a locally-sourced clay pot water filter – in Taha, a village adjacent to Tamale. While the current focus of work is in household treatment for safe drinking water, PHW also engages in sanitation efforts.

After speaking with local villages, it became clear that improved sanitation was a priority but was inaccessible due to lack of resources and high costs.  In addition, many people lack an understanding of the relationship between improved sanitation and their health.  So, how can we help?We decided to start with the children.  Children will be making decisions in the future and will also influence their parents now.  In June 2013, PHW built a 6-stall toilet block in 30 days for a school in the village of Taha.  Since this project was so successful, we decided to keep the momentum going!  We are planning to build the same toilet block for the neighboring village of Gbalahi.  Why give?Your contribution not only allows for the construction of the proposed toilet block, but also employs local workers from Gbalahi and the surrounding villages.  Your contribution ensures the the children of this village will be better protected from disease and will begin educating the children and their parents on safe hygiene practices.  Ultimately, your contribution will change lives. What We Need & What You GetOur costs primarily include the labor and material costs for the toilet block, monitoring to ensure sustainability, travel and living expenses for one graduate student to oversee the construction, and some small miscellaneous expenses.  All funds will be directed towards this project and if excess funds are received, we will begin planning additional toilet blocks for surrounding villages!  A detailed breakdown of costs is available as an image in the gallery for your reference on this page.What will you get?We have four levels of incentives for giving.
If you give $20, we will be forever thankful and your name will be included in the list of contributors.
If you give $50, we will send you a picture of the completed toilet block with a project report.
If you give $100, we will send you a local piece of artwork from Ghana.
If you give $1,000, we will include your name on the toilet block as a key contributor to the project.  We will send you a picture of your name on the toilet block after completion.

Who will this help?This toilet block will serve 200 primary school children and influence many others as well.  Not only will this project keep the children and teachers safe and healthy, but will begin to educate on better sanitation practices, keeping future children safe and healthy as well.Other Ways You Can HelpIf you're unable to contribute, please pass this along to your friends and family that may be interested.  This is a very important and time-sensitive problem that can be addressed!  We encourage you to research the problem to better understand it's global significance and see how you can help make important change happen!Pure Home Water in the News: http://web.mit.edu/newsoffice/2013/long-haul-to-bring-clean-water-to-developing-nations-1210.html",0.0,0,"1 Campaign
|","Santa Barbara, United States",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/toilets-for-schools-improving-sanitation-in-ghana/pica

Please help me renovate three improvised primary schools around my
village in Sierra Leone, West Africa.
Education-Alhaji, USA.
Short
Summary:
I am trying to renovate three primary schools (Sierra Leone
Wesleyan Primary school, Maforay and SLMB Primary schools) attended by approximately
900 students around my village in Sierra Leone, West Africa.
One of the primary schools is my former school.  As a boy, I attended the SLMB primary school
until my village was destroyed in 1997 during Sierra Leone’s civil war. As a
fifth grader, I was allowed to stay for a semester when my parents could not
afford my $5.00 tuition at the time.
As a former student, I hope I can give these children
opportunities that were never given to me: like a library, a decent classroom
or a computer lab—with your support we can build dreams, with dreams we can
change minds. I hope you can help!
Why
Village Primary Schools?
I know personally the
difficulties that these children are facing every day.  Most of these children are coming from surrounding
villages and they walk about 2-3 miles to get to school. Education—is their
only hope out of poverty. So they come everyday walking an average of 250 miles
each school year. The roof leaks whenever it rains, flooding the classrooms—disrupting
classes several days a week during the rainy seasoning. Together, we can save
the last hope of my village. We can rebuild these schools
better future through education. <span> Many people wait and see if their condition will
improve rather than seek assistance.
My
History
I was born
and raised in Sierra Leone, West Africa and returned for first visit
since I fled our civil war  as a teenager
about 13 years ago.  l left my home and family, alone, as a boy due to the
terrible conditions there at the time. I finally made it to the Philadelphia,
after years of hardship and duress, and enrolled in public high school as a
junior.  With pretty much 7 years of formal schooling, and purely through
dint of will, intelligence, and incredible drive, l graduated from the bottom
5% of my class. I ultimately moved to a local community college in Texas,
worked my way through before transferring to the University of North Texas, and
funded my entire education without any loans or government assistance.
was accepted at the University of Pennsylvania and on target to graduate with
an M.A. in Economic Development and Growth next May.  From a child hiding
in a tragic and dangerous civil war to the Ivy League!
Now I am
thinking PhD…I hope I only become the first of my
village and not the last. My aim is to extend the same opportunities to
the children in my village.
How Was
This Project Developed?
<h4><span>In June 2013, I was accepted to intern for <a href=""http://www.linkedin.com/search?search=&amp
column5: trk=prof-exp-company-name"" rel=""noopener nofollow""><span>FXB Center for Health and Human

column1: Rights, Harvard School of Public Health in Freetown, Sierra Leone. Before my trip, I
shipped a barrel of school supplies for my old school (SLMB) but distributed it
among the two other primary schools close by. Over the following months since I
returned back to the US, I have collected hundreds of books and some sporting
gears to be sent in January with the help of an NGO.
What is Our Timetable?
<h4>I
hope to return in March during my spring break holiday and begin renovation on
the schools and distribute all the school supplies among the three schools. If
we raise enough money, we hope to rebuild my old school because the building is
very unsafe for the children. An estimate of $7,000 will cover the entire
building cost.
Who Will
Manage This Project?
I will deliver all school supplies directly to the students and I will
monitor any future construction to ensure compliance with building standards
and accountability. I made a promised to those kids and if this project fails
it will be my fault.
If you
would like to be part of this great endeavor, here are other ways you can help:
1.  Share the
link with your social network on Facebook, Twitter, Pinterest, etc
2.  Host a
party: (This is a great way to support if you have a strong network of possible
supporters. You invite the people. I share my story. I make the appeal. We
reach the goal!)
If you can
think of another way to help me reach my goal, I am very interested in hearing
you ideas. Email me at: saccoh04@yahoo.com or http://saccoh04.wordpress.com/
Who Can
Donate?
Anyone can donate. This campaign begins with a goal of $10,000
which will give us a strong base from which we can repair all the broken desks
and chairs, build three new latrines, and libraries.  Any amount you donate—from $1 upwards—deeply
touches our heart, and for this we thank you so much.
If we can secure a proper school building for these kids, it will
impact their local community in a very positive way and will offer a fantastic
example of what can be done to turn despair into hope, and disempowerment to
courageous action. In today's world we need examples like this. Happy
Thanksgiving and Merry Christmas.

My name is Dominique and I am a 22-year-old college student originally from San Francisco. My passion includes the holistic health field and helping others to heal using natural remedies. I enjoy incorporating meditation, essential oils and a vegan lifestyle into my personal health and I want to share this information with others. I feel that now is one of the few times that I can freely donate my time volunteering and helping others.

I have never been out of the country, so my goal for 2015 is to volunteer with the GIVE international foundation. I have already been accepted to the program, but now I need the funds for the down payment, my passport and visa, insurance and my flight to and from Tanzania. I also receive academic credit for volunteering!

Being able to help others is very important to me, especially those who are without sufficient resources, including fresh water. This experience will not only help me to broaden my horizon, but it will also give me the opportunity to impact the lives of others in a positive, healthy way.
• The total amount due for the program is $2205.The academic course is another $1200, totaling $3405.
• The flight is estimated to be about $2000 for round trip.
• I also require funds for insurance, my visa and passport, totaling around $500.
Thank you for reading and your donations!

“Kash mein aapko apne sath ghar le ja sakti. Phir aap har roz English homework mein meri help kar sakte.”

(I wish I could take you home with me – then you could help me with my English homework everyday)

-- Neelam (aged 12) a student at the Arpana Trust, a non-profit educating children from slums in New Delhi, India


Neelam is not alone in her struggle to learn without a support network at home. One of the biggest challenges faced by students in India is the quality of public school education.

Hello, Seekho(seekho means “learn” in Hindi) is our vision for a comprehensive solution to these problems, and one of the fastest ways for students like Neelam to improve their English skills, to spark their potential and passion for learning, and boost their self-confidence.


Hello, Seekho is a learning tool that provides free audio lessons through the extensive reach of mobile phones in India to supplement government school education. Hello, Seekho’s comprehensive curriculum is created by teachers with experience in curriculum development in leading schools in India, and has been vetted by educational consultants. A vast selection of short pre-recorded audio clips is available on our toll free number, and are pre-recorded with professional voice actors and musicians at a local studio.
column5:
/>

Vaasvi and Kasturi began Hello, Seekho  during their sophomore year at Princeton University after realising that they shared a similar passion for improving access to English education in India. Last November we sat in a froyo cafe in Princeton, past closing hours, and listed all the problems in India that we wanted to solve. We picked education because we both felt it had the most long-lasting impact, and so Hello, Seekho was born.


Having both grown up in India, we share a nuanced understanding of the intricacies of the Indian education system. Our native fluency in Hindi, connections with local non-profits, experience teaching and developing curriculum, enthusiasm from the success of our pilot, and finally, our determination to close the education gap in India are the colours with which we plan to paint a brighter future for students in India.




This past summer, we launched a pilot in New Delhi using the $5000 seed funding we received from winning a seed funding competition at Princeton. We launched a pilot in August 2014 and have received positive feedback and testimonials from students in the slum colonies where the pilot was launched.
column7:
/>

Having launched a successful pilot, our next steps are to analyze the data and increase our impact. While we have received thousands of phone calls, the process of streamlining our curriculum to reflect our listener’s preferences is a continuously ongoing one. From December 2014 onwards, we will partner with the Ahvaan Trust, a non-profit that carries out teacher training in government schools, to market our service and conduct workshops within these schools.

We still have a long way to go, and many students to reach, but students like Neelam are our founding and continuous inspiration.
column20:
/>


If you would like to get involved, please email us with a short statement explaining your interest at kasturi@helloseekho.com and vaasvi@helloseekho.com

Colin's Elementary School Walk-a-thon!

Colin is participating with his Kindergarten class in his elementary school's walk-a-thon to raise funds for education. This site makes each campaign put a minimum of $500 as the fundraising goal, but really Colin only hopes to raise $150. His father and I are taking him house to house in our neighborhood to earn sponsors himself, but I have created this campaign for those he can't visit directly. As such, we aren't looking for a large donation from each sponsor. Even a $1.00 would be great, but a $5.00 donation makes Colin exclaim, ""Wow! That's so nice of them!"" As kindergartener's interests go, he is not wishing to earn $150 for the prize they are offering the kids (an entry in a drawing to win a t-shirt and a trip during school hours to an ice cream parlor along with play time at a park, for the child and a friend) but his primary excitement is over the lanyard he will receive for participating. Lanyards are apparently completely neato to kindergarteners. 100% of the funds the walk-a-thon raises will go directly to the children's education, so your donation will not be divided for charitable administrative costs. It takes a village to raise a child, and you can support this child with as little as $1!

<span style=""font-size: 24px

I wanted to thank you all for taking time to stop by my page. My name is Jennifer Meneray for those that do not know me already and I am passionate about advocating for social justice within our community. To better serve my community, I have started this campaign to help raise the funds needed to get me into a Graduate level program. This includes but is not limited to application fees, transcript fees, as well as the Graduate Record Examination (GRE). Scary Stuff-- I know, but I have been studying, I promise!

My goal is to enter a program that analyzes the effect institutional oppression has on cultural values worldwide and how that connects to violence towards different gender identities. I will be applying to programs such as Feminist Studies, Women Studies, Gender Studies, etc. and will be looking for a program that focuses on International politics. The possibility of a joint program in Feminist Studies and International Politics has also crossed my mind, but without your help these possibilities are limited.

After graduating from my future program I wish to work towards ending violence against women on an international scale either by entering the political arena or working for the United Nations UNiTE to End Violence Against Women Program (http://endviolence.un.org/about.shtml).

I have been out of school for two years so I am currently paying back student loans from my undergraduate career. This has caused financial strain for me and I do not want it to be the reason I postpone my dreams longer. I appreciate everything you have done for me in the past and you all inspire me to continue to my journey towards my goals. With everyone's help I know that anything is possible and I hope you view any contribution to my campaign as an investment in my future rather than a simple donation.

For those that wish to contribute but cannot do so financially, simply spreading the word would be enough. If you could let people in your life know how you know me and how I have impacted your life in a positive way then maybe they will see a donation as an investment in something positive. Encouraging emails are also helpful so if you all could help fund my future I would greatly be appreciative.

""So let us wage, so let us wage a glorious struggle against illiteracy, poverty and terrorism, let us pick up our books and our pens, they are the most powerful weapons. One child, one teacher, one book and one pen can change the world. Education is the only solution. Education first.""-- Malala Yousafzai

#30Days of ThanksgivingLO 

You may not know this about me, but I had the AMAZING opportunity to go through a program called Legal Outreach in high school. Legal Outreach works with students from underserved neighborhoods around NYC and prepares them to succeed in high school, college, and beyond.  

I'm fundraising this November to make it possible for more students like me to go through Legal Outreach.  

My Story  

My name is Shueanna Harrinandan and I grew up in an underserved neighborhood in New York City.

Because of Legal Outreach, I was encouraged to apply to colleges and attended St. John's University. LO supported me beginning in 8th grade, and I left LO four years later inspired and equipped for college. 

Your support can change the lives of more students like me!

Your Support Will... 

Make it possible for more students like me to go through Legal Outreach for four years of free programming, including a debate program, SAT prep, writing classes, mentoring, college application workshops, and much more! 

Of the students LO supports:
• 100% graduated HS on time (only 66% of NYC public school students do)
• 99% went on to colleges and universities
Other Ways You Can Help

","#30Days of ThanksgivingLO You may not know this about me, but I had the AMAZING opportunity to go through a program called Legal Outreach in high school. Legal Outreach works with students from underserved neighborhoods around NYC and prepares them to succeed in high school, college, and beyond.  I'm fundraising this November to make it possible for more students like me to go through Legal Outreach.  My Story  My name is Shueanna Harrinandan and I grew up in an underserved neighborhood in New York City.Because of Legal Outreach, I was encouraged to apply to colleges and attended St. John's University. LO supported me beginning in 8th grade, and I left LO four years later inspired and equipped for college. Your support can change the lives of more students like me!Your Support Will... Make it possible for more students like me to go through Legal Outreach for four years of free programming, including a debate program, SAT prep, writing classes, mentoring, college application workshops, and much more! Of the students LO supports:
100% graduated HS on time (only 66% of NYC public school students do)
99% went on to colleges and universities

Our Project

Assalamu aleykum,

We are the Chronicles of Faith, you've seen us on YouTube as entertainers, but we want to be instructors. One thing some of you might not know about us, is that we take Islam very seriously, and we are dedicated students of knowledge. We want to go to bayyinah in order to improve ourselves, we already raised a little over $30000 USD, for the 9 month ""dream program"" as well as passed all the necessary tests and interviews to make it through. We need your help to fund the extra $14000 USD needed in order for us to survive there. Help fund our Arabic and Islamic studies &
column3:
in Canada.

This is an important project for our community, especially in Montreal, because we don't have many teachers or students of knowledge capable of teaching the basics of our religion. Also we are all experienced Da'ees, who have been giving da'wah for as long as we can remember, with huge goals and aspirations. Together, by the Grace of Allah, we were able to get over 30 shahadahs in the past 3 years, and we have been given a big role and influence by Allah SWT, and we hope to stay sincere and keep serving His deen, however we can. 

Our eventual goal is to open up something similar to the Bayyinah institute but here in Canada, to help the travel costs and make it more accessible to those who desire to study Arabic here.  Through your contributions, not only will you be able to get a sadaqa jariyah (continuous in reward) for allowing us to teach others (as the Prophet taught us), but you will be able to also bring our da'wah to an international level, through our entertainment, and through our teaching. May Allah reward you for your help and contributions, and please spread the word however you can (E-mail, Facebook, Twitter, etc...)

What We Need &
column4:
What You Get

The amount needed for our funding is $14000 USD. With this funding, we will be able to cover all of our expenses for the remaining 9 months (September until June). These costs cover rent, tuition, traveling costs. Also part of the funds will go in investing into recording and editing equipment (computer/laptop, camera, green screen and lighting), so that we may continue our recordings in Dallas. We will also use this opportunity to bring in a number of new hosts if they accept such as an episode with Nouman Ali Khan, Omar Suleiman, Abdul Nasir Jangda, etc. 

In return, we will set up a number of perks depending on the amount that is donated. Here's a list of what you can get, insha'Allah, if you help us!

If we reach $5 000
- We will release a kufi tutorial video
- We will release an extra episode of Ugly Truths for Season 5

If we reach $10 000
- We will release an extra segment (a very exciting new series of episodes).  
Note: NOT UGLY TRUTHS

If we reach $14 000
- 2 extra episodes of Ugly Truths while in Dallas
- We will try to do an episode with Nouman Ali Khan or Omar Suleiman or Abdul  Nasir Jangda or an exciting similar host. 
- More video logs about our stay and experience in Bayyinah, so that you can follow our journey with us. 

+ All the previously mentioned rewards!

Also we have included a list of perks down below depending on the amounts pledged.
column10:
>Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute financially, then here is a list of things you can do.

Share this page all over your social media outlets (Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, etc...) 

Make Du'a for us, and for the success of this project. 

Share the word with your family and friends, and make some noise about our campaign.

Remember that if we don't reach our target, then we won't be able to maximize our benefit from the total amount donated.

HELLO and thank you for stopping by our page! 

The Black Law Students Association is a student organization committed to its members’ professional development, academic achievement, social awareness, and community activism.

Our goal is to be active within our community and to ensure our members excel academically. We strive to cultivate the law school experience through service to our community, social action, and unity amongst our peers. This includes political education to the minority community in San Diego and motivating its youth to pursue higher education.  We also provide networking opportunities with local attorneys, judges, and entrepreneurs as well as career building and academic workshops to ensure the success of our members. 

 As an organization we provide a forum for members to discuss and remedy issues of concern. Advocate programs aimed at increasing legal awareness and support in under-served communities. Facilitate social and professional interaction between current BLSA members and alumni of Thomas Jefferson School of Law and the greater legal community.

What We Need &
• 25th Annual Aids Walk taking place on Saturday, September 27, 2014.
• Making Strides Against Breast Cancer Walk on Saturday, October 19, 2014!
• Ferguson Panel Discussion in partnership with National Lawyers Guild on Friday, September 26, 2014.
• Study Halls held twice monthly where we provide students with snacks.
• Alumni Weekend.
• Partnership with CLIMB to mentor at Crawford High School
• Holiday Food Drive and feeding the homeless.

The Impact

These events are just a few that are scheduled during our 2014-2015 academic year, but we need assistance to ensure that our members are not only able to participate financially but to host events to the best of our ability. 

Being a law student comes with many challenges academically, financially, and socially. Your help will enable us to continue our efforts in giving back to the community worry free by hosting panel
column2:
> discussions, feeding the homeless, and donating to causes that our near and dear to our hearts.

Please help us by donating anything you can so that BLSA can meet its goals. Any amount given is a BLESSING to us and will be used to give back to the San Diego community. 

Thank You :)

BACKGROUND:

During January 2015 FAI (International Aeronautic Federation) have finally defined WingSuit Flying as a regular skydiving discipline and have announced the first Wingsuit World Cup, this has attracted huge anticipation amongst not only the Wingsuiting fraternity, but the skydiving industry as whole – a truly great achievement for the sport, and another badge of honour for extreme sports enthusiasts.

The World Cup will be hosted by the Army Parachute Association at Netheravon Airfield, Wiltshire, UK and will take place between Monday 25th and Friday 29th May.

In order to partecipate to the World Cup a competitor must be nominated by his national authority as National delegation.

Italian skydiving authority (AeCI) cannot afford to pay for its own competitors because, as it happends in many other countries, the budget for international competitions as been decided at the end of 2014 (the World Cup has been announced at January 2015). For this reason AeCI is  asking to competitors who are interested to take part at the World Cup to pay it by themself.
What We Need &
column2:
What You Get

We need money, for training hard.
You get nothing material, except our gratitude.

but:
If you are a potential sponsor, interested in a sponsorship agreement, please contact me, we have a lot to talk of !

column1: mail: pistolesi.marco@gmail.com
<span style=""color: rgb(0, 0, 0)

please share this link to every potential sponsor, help us to gain a sponsorship and I will find a way to be grateful !





---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
BACKGROUND:

Durante il mese di gennaio 2015 la FAI (Federazione Aeronautica Internazionale) ha finalmente definito il volo in tuta alare come un disciplina ufficiale del paracadutismo e ha anche annunciato la prima Coppa del Mondo di Wingsuit, questo ha creato enorme attesa non solo nella comunità Wingsuit, ma anche in tutta l'industria del paracadutismo - un vero grande successo per lo sport, ed un altro distintivo d'onore per gli appassionati di sport estremi.
La Coppa del Mondo sarà ospitata dalla Army Parachute Association a Netheravon, Inghilterra e si svolgerà tra Lunedi 25 e Venerdì 29 maggio.
Per partecipare alla Coppa del Mondo un concorrente deve essere nominato dalla sua autorità nazionale (Coni ed AeroClub d'Italia) quale ""delegazione nazionale"".

AeroClub Italia non può permettersi di pagare per i propri concorrenti in quanto il budget è già stato totalmente stanziato, come accade in molti altri paesi, a fine 2014 (la Coppa del Mondo è stata annunciata a gennaio) e chiede quindi ai singoli atleti interessati a partecipare di pagare in autonomia la propria competizione.
DI COSA ABBIAMO BISOGNO E COSA OTTERRETE
Abbiamo bisogno di soldi, per un duro e serio allenamento... si tratta della prima coppa del mondo e la fuori si gioca duro !
siamo sinceri: non avrete nulla di materiale, solo la nostra totale e sincera gratitudine.
ma:
Se sei un potenziale sponsor, interessato a sottoscrivere un contratto di sponsorizzazione contattami, abbiamo molto di cui parlare !
ALTRI MODI PER AIUTARE
Condividete questo link, ad ogni potenziale sponsor che conoscete, parlate di noi, aiutateci ad acquisire una sponsorizzazione e troveremo un modo per esservi grati !

In order to partecipate to the World Cup a competitor must be nominated by his national authority as National delegation.Italian skydiving authority (AeCI) cannot afford to pay for its own competitors because, as it happends in many other countries, the budget for international competitions as been decided at the end of 2014 (the World Cup has been announced at January 2015). For this reason AeCI is  asking to competitors who are interested to take part at the World Cup to pay it by themself.

English:

I am reaching out to you to ask for help in pursuing my dream: I am ready to  get certified as a Life Coach! 

For the past 4 years I have been preparing myself to work with people. I started by going through a two-year training to get ordained as a Minister at the Center of Sacred Studies. My fascination on peace grew bigger and so did my intent on understanding suffering, conflict and resolution. This lead me to take the Choice in Coaching course by Arbinger Institute which gave me more tools to continue my work with people. This was not a certified coaching training, but it opened my eyes to Life Coaching as a career. Which lead me to my dream of taking the two-year Accredited Coach Training Program by The Institute for Life Coach Training. By fulfilling this dream, I will receive the tools and gain the knowledge to build a solid career to help more people. 

Thank you for supporting my campaign and being part of my journey of helping more people! 

 Español:

Estoy acercándome a ustedes para pedir su ayuda para lograr el sueño de certificarme como Coach de Vida.

Durante los últimos 4 años he estado preparándome para trabajar con la gente. Empecé formalmente mi recorrido cuando hice un entrenamiento de dos años en el Centro de Estudios Sagrados donde mi fascinación sobre el tema de la paz creció, al igual que mi propósito de entender el sufrimiento, los conflictos y la resolución de ellos. Esto me llevó a tomar el entrenamiento The Choice in Coaching por Arbinger Institute, en donde descubrí que sí se puede alcanzar más plenitud en nuestra vida y en donde obtuve herramientas para guiar a las personas de una forma más exitosa. A través de ese entrenamiento mi misión de vida se volvió más tangible y mi sueño de tomar un entrenamiento de dos años de acreditación para certificarme como coach por The Institute for Life Coach Training cobró vida, pues al tomar este entrenamiento recibiré las herramientas, los conocimientos y las credenciales para construir una carrera sólida para poder ayudar a más personas.

¡Gracias por apoyar mi campaña y ser parte de mi recorrido!

Short Summary

My name is Tim Blewitt, and in October 2014 I ventured to Brussels, Belgium to attend the highly selective international theatre  program at L'ecole de Lassaad.  I attended this school for one year and improved my education on physical theatre, movement, anatomy, and improvisation, by utilizing observations of the natural world to become a movement specialist in the most theatrical sense possible.

My campaign is to help me finish the second and final year of this  program so that I may have the opportunity to fully immerse myself in the entire curriculum of the Lassaad pedagogy.  Without the final year of this pedagogy, my education in this field will not be nearly as satisfying, and will always feel incomplete to me.  If you are able to contribute to my campaign, you will not only help me to finish one of my most passionate dreams of attending this school, but you will also enhance my education as a serious theatre practitioner.

What I Need &
column2:
What You Get

In order to pay the tuition of the first trimester, I need $2,000 dollars.  All of this money will go directly to The Lassaad School for tuition.

***In return for your contribution, I will send you a picture of myself in the city of Brussels applying one of the many physical/theatrical elements that I have been learning at the school.

The Impact

As one of my teachers explained to me at the school, ""Everything we do in life is interesting.""  Every movement we make, every action we take, has a cause, a purpose, and an effect.  The education that I am receiving now has truly revolutionized the way that I look at human interaction, and the way that I behold the beauty of everyday life.  Your contribution will allow me to continue on this path of ever-improving my perspective of natural life, in addition to helping me specialize my continuously growing craft of theatre performance.


Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to contribute financially, I appreciate your taking the time to read about my campaign.  If I could ask you to take just a few minutes more to share this campaign with friends and family  --  anyone who might be able to help  --  it would make a world of difference to me.  Thank you so much, and I look forward to sharing my adventures with you!

This is a personal funding page to help contribute to the photographic and filmic production costs involved in the book ""Dreamers and Doers"" and a film about the importance of supporting education for adolescent girls in developing countries.

Sale of the book goes directly to funding for study material to Tanzanian children and any surplus received on top of the production costs within the $15.000 goal on this page goes directly to Ladies Trekking and Impatiens Kilimanjari Foundation.
http://www.ladiestrekking.com/
http://ikfoundation.com

It's a beautiful initiative by Ladies Trekking and I'm honoured to have been asked to be part of it and as a collective with other women help spread the word about the right for education for girls, as well as inspire others to climb mountains – whether for real or metaphorically.
So please help me help them.
WHY IS EDUCATION FOR ADOLESCENT GIRLS IMPORTANT?
Check out this informative clip from THE GIRL EFFECT
http://www.girleffect.org/why-girls/
THE CHARITY'S MISSION

The aim is through the book “Dreamers and Doers” to reduce global poverty and gender inequality by supporting and promoting girls’ education in Tanzania. Each ambassador of the book, of which I am one, will furthermore help to spread the message, in my case by making a promotional film with insight into some of these girls lives, which will be produced in conjunction with the climb.

Education leads to better opportunities for a decent livelihood and economic independence. It enhances personal confidence and well-being. The more educated we are the less charity we need in our lives.
In Tanzania 400.000 children lack the opportunity to get proper school education. 70% of those are girls and more than 4000 schools have a shortage of study material.
THE BOOK ""DREAMERS AND DOERS""

The book “Dreamers and Doers” will be a photographic book featuring a collection of inspirational stories and  life changing moments of women who have been to Kilimanjaro. It is to be published in June 2013. The sale of the book supports Tanzanian children with study material.
Each buyer of “Dreamers and Doers” has the opportunity to track the outcome of their good deed. Relevant information will be published in the book and can also be found on the ladiestrekking website.
Check out the mock-up of the book here:
http://www.ladiestrekking.com/wp-content/upload...
SUPPORTING TANZANIAN GIRLS WITH STUDY MATERIAL AND SCHOOL FEES

The journey of the textbooks to the schoolchildren is organised and implemented by the charitable foundation Impatiens Kilimanjari. Their members are international professional women who have teaching experience in Tanzania and are well aware of the country’s educational challenges. The aim is to pin point the recipients who need our support most and to provide them with the textbooks that are compatible with the curriculum taught in Tanzanian schools.
Furthermore 10 girls will be supported financially through their entire school education.
THE TREK

In order to make sure the idea and message of the book reaches the readers, ten women of different nationalities have been invited to be ambassadors of the book and trek to Kilimanjaro in February 2013 and take the message “Everyone is entitled to education” to the summit. This trek will become an important part of the book.
http://www.ladiestrekking.com/book/trip/
MY CONTRIBUTION

As well as being an ambassador and writing my own personal story for the book, I will be photographing the trek in February 2013 to be published in the book, as well as making a promotional film featuring some of the teenage masai girls whose education the charity supports, to help spread the word about why it is globally important to focus on education for girls.
Read about the girls here:
http://www.ladiestrekking.com/10-tanzanian-girl...
YOUR SUPPORT

In order to make this trek, book and film a reality I’m applying for funding for the photographic and filmic production costs involved in this project. Any surplus that I receive within the $15.000 goal on this page goes directly to Ladies Trekking.
A BIT ABOUT ME

I’m a Danish film director and photographer based in London. I have an honours degree in Graphic Design from Central St. Martin’s School of Art in London. Before moving onto directing I creatively assisted commercials director Chris Palmer at Gorgeous in London and have been part of creating and shooting numerous award-winning commercials across the world. In 2010 I debuted with the experimental film album 'Black Summer by The Pony Tales' which premiered at Cph:Dox festival in Copenhagen with a sold out live show. I tend to have a strong visual approach to my work as well as a fascination of human lives and stories. I’m represented by Academy Films in London.
http://www.nadia-marquard-otzen.com/
http://www.academy-plus.com/categories/nadia

","This is a personal funding page to help contribute to the photographic and filmic production costs involved in the book ""Dreamers and Doers"" and a film about the importance of supporting education for adolescent girls in developing countries.

Sale of the book goes directly to funding for study material to Tanzanian children and any surplus received on top of the production costs within the $15.000 goal on this page goes directly to Ladies Trekking and Impatiens Kilimanjari Foundation.
http://www.ladiestrekking.com/
http://ikfoundation.com

It's a beautiful initiative by Ladies Trekking and I'm honoured to have been asked to be part of it and as a collective with other women help spread the word about the right for education for girls, as well as inspire others to climb mountains – whether for real or metaphorically.
So please help me help them.
WHY IS EDUCATION FOR ADOLESCENT GIRLS IMPORTANT?
Check out this informative clip from THE GIRL EFFECT
http://www.girleffect.org/why-girls/
THE CHARITY'S MISSION

The aim is through the book “Dreamers and Doers” to reduce global poverty and gender inequality by supporting and promoting girls’ education in Tanzania. Each ambassador of the book, of which I am one, will furthermore help to spread the message, in my case by making a promotional film with insight into some of these girls lives, which will be produced in conjunction with the climb.

Education leads to better opportunities for a decent livelihood and economic independence. It enhances personal confidence and well-being. The more educated we are the less charity we need in our lives.
In Tanzania 400.000 children lack the opportunity to get proper school education. 70% of those are girls and more than 4000 schools have a shortage of study material.
THE BOOK ""DREAMERS AND DOERS""

The book “Dreamers and Doers” will be a photographic book featuring a collection of inspirational stories and  life changing moments of women who have been to Kilimanjaro. It is to be published in June 2013. The sale of the book supports Tanzanian children with study material.
Each buyer of “Dreamers and Doers” has the opportunity to track the outcome of their good deed. Relevant information will be published in the book and can also be found on the ladiestrekking website.

Overview

The website is the central hub for the Critical Theory Research Network (CTRN). It contains a publicly accessible members list, the community blog, general information on the network, and quick forms for new members to join. CTRN is not currently attached to nor funded by any outside institution. The website is currently paid for out-of-pocket by one person, at $496 a year. CTRN could use your support! For one person it's a bit much, but for a large community, it is not much.

In Short

Founded in October, 2016, the Critical Theory Research Network (CTRN) helps connect people interested in Critical Theory from all over the world. CTRN does not charge member dues, and is not beholden to the distorting demands of outside companies or institutions. It is a public sphere where Critical Theory scholars can meet, exchange ideas, and coordinate projects. Spaces like this are a crucial way to keep communities of scholarly inquiry vibrant and free from the neoliberal pressures that constrain so many of today's universities. 

Keeping the website up costs money. Since CTRN does not generate revenue, the website is currently funded by one person out-of-pocket, at $496 a year. With a modest number of donations to this campaign, the community could generate funding to cover all costs for the website through 2019.

What We Need &
column2:
What You Get

To cover costs of the website for another year, we need to raise $496. This includes:

column1: • web hosting ($6/month)
• wordpress site ($9/month)
• premium theme ($24/year)
• Jetpack Premium ($9/month)
• domain ($35/year)
• a certificate to keep the website secure ($149/year)

If/when we reach our target amount ($525), the campaign will include a book raffle - contributors who have given any amount - in other words $1 or more - are entered for the chance to win a paperback copy of Critical Theory and Authoritarian Populism. If we reach $550, two copies of the book will be raffled off. If we reach $575, then three copies, and so on.

There will also be a second raffle if/when we reach our target ($525). All Brazilian contributors will be eligible to win a copy of O Probema do Populismo. Only one of these will be give away.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you cannot afford a contribution, you can still provide key support by letting others know about this campaign. Please share on social media to help us reach our goal!

“We could probably save a fortune, both emotionally for kids and their families, as well as taxpayer dollars, if we cloned The DOME.”
— Judge Judith Sheindlin

The DOME Project, an acronym for Developing Opportunities through Meaningful Education, is a 501c(3) nonprofit organization that was founded in 1973 by John Simon. The DOME Project is committed to improving the lives of young people who rely on the services we provide in the areas of alternative to detention, college preparation, and tutoring. The DOME Project seeks funding to support the expansion and development of our programming in order to support our most important asset: our youth. With an expansion of staff and programs, we anticipate an increase in the number of youth we provide services to and we hope to effectuate a greater impact for the underserved youth in New York City.
<div>
What We Need
The DOME Project seeks $10,000 in funding to provide continued assistance with our three flagship programs:

column5: >The Alternative to Detention Program: Bridge to Success is an extraordinarily successful and cost-effective effort that provides young people with counseling, school and court advocacy, life skills development, and guidance toward educational and vocational opportunities to both prevent at-risk youth from further involvement in criminal activity and reduce future involvement in the criminal justice system.

>The Academic Tutoring Program continues to serve our traditional population of disadvantaged youth with distinct educational needs by pairing youths with a volunteer tutor for supervised subject specific academic sessions. Program participants receive highly individualized educational support from their volunteer tutor often more rigorous and challenging than the work the student receives in school.
>The College Prep Program successfully assists many students in gaining entry to colleges and prep schools through intensive academic support services.

column1: If you donate, you will get one of the many perks listed on our page!
<div>
The Impact
All donations are <span style=""text-decoration: underline
column2: >TAX DEDUCTIBLE.  Your donation will allow us to:

column1: Serve a larger number of at risk youth who need assistance with trouble(s) with the law, college preparation, and tutoring/mentoring.
Enable our staff members to receive professional development training.
Update our website to make it more contemporary and allow us to purcase space to host referral forms for those seeking to put us in contact wih at risk youth.
Purchase photography and video equipment to document the stories of the youth in our programs.
SAVE your taxpayer dollars!
<div>
Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot donate your financial support, please donate your time or talent to the organization. We will be having a silent auction at our Gala Event on Novemeber 14, 2012. Please feel free to donate items and/or business services for our auction. Please contact kevin@domeproject.org with any ideas or questions. Also, please feel free to donate your time by volunteering at the DOME Project or providing access to internships for our youth.

Also, you can vote for us on Chase Community Giving at the link below. http://apps.facebook.com/chasecommunitygiving/c...
Learn more about the DOME Project
www.domeproject.org
http://www.youtube.com/user/domeprojectnyc

The DOME Project, an acronym for Developing Opportunities through Meaningful Education, is a 501c(3) nonprofit organization that was founded in 1973 by John Simon. The Academic Tutoring Program continues to serve our traditional population of disadvantaged youth with distinct educational needs by pairing youths with a volunteer tutor for supervised subject specific academic sessions. <h3><strong id=""internal-source-marker_0.8713261198718101"" style=""""><span style=""color: #000000
column12: >I'd like to introduce my granddaughter, Annmarie.  She is 14 years old and in the 8th grade.  Annmarie is one of the sweetest, most hardworking &amp
column13: caring young people. Annmarie, from a very young age, has always been what I call a peacekeeper. She has never been able to stand others to bully or be unkind to other people.  Whenever she has witnessed incidents of name calling or a peer being left out of something, she speaks up.  I remember an incident that happened when a classmate was being teased and she boldly told the other child, ""how would you like that?""  and then asked, ""is that how you really want to act?"" This was when she was only 12 years old. Peace was made between the two friends.  Interestingly, it doesn’t matter if the person being teased is a person who is a friend or not .  Even people that haven’t been the nicest to her, have been on the receiving end of her interventions.  She has been practicing anti-bullying before she had ever heard of the term.

column12: >Also, she is so hardworking.   I can ask her to help in any way including cooking and cleaning and she has always done it with a smile on her face.  It doesn’t matter what it is.  Also, even though she is only 14, she chose to get a job this summer in order to earn money including some seed money for this trip. She worked for a local farmer selling corn at their corn stand and at the local farmer's market with other teens.  Last year, when there was an announcement at our church asking if you had coats you could donate for those less fortunate, she, on her own, decided to have her own coat drive. She designed her own flyer, dropped them off in our neighborhood and then went back a few days later pulling a read wagon collecting the coats. (See small picture above of her with coats)  That is the heart of Annmarie.
column23: >So now to the purpose of this campaign.  Her 8th grade class is visiting Washington D.C., Pennsylvania and New York City this Spring as their 8th grade trip.  It is the trip of a lifetime.  They will be visiting all the places they are learning about this year in American History.  They will visit an Amish community.  They also get to see a live Broadway Show in New York City.  It is a life experience she will never forget.  It breaks my heart that she might have to miss it.  She lives with her mom.  Neither her mom, her dad or we, as her grandparents have the ability to pay for this trip without help.  We will definitely contribute, but it is impossible for any one of us to fund this trip for her.  I hate to think of her missing out on such a wonderful life experience, especially in light of the fabulous, giving young lady that she is.  I am asking you to please consider making a contribution, large or small, to her account to help fund her trip.  The funds will pay for the cost of the trip, meals and incidentals.  In Annmarie style, she is doing her part, fundraising by selling candles and candy bars.  If you are unable to contribute anything, would you be so kind as to “share” her campaign with your friends and family?  It would be so greatly appreciated.
column34: >I hope you have enjoyed getting to know my junior peacekeeper, Annmarie and will find it in your heart to give a little or a lot.

column1: ","I'd like to introduce my granddaughter, Annmarie.  She is 14 years old and in the 8th grade.  Annmarie is one of the sweetest, most hardworking & caring young people. Annmarie, from a very young age, has always been what I call a peacekeeper. She has never been able to stand others to bully or be unkind to other people.  Whenever she has witnessed incidents of name calling or a peer being left out of something, she speaks up.  I remember an incident that happened when a classmate was being teased and she boldly told the other child, ""how would you like that?""  and then asked, ""is that how you really want to act?"" Also, she is so hardworking.   I can ask her to help in any way including cooking and cleaning and she has always done it with a smile on her face.  It doesn’t matter what it is.  Also, even though she is only 14, she chose to get a job this summer in order to earn money including some seed money for this trip. She designed her own flyer, dropped them off in our neighborhood and then went back a few days later pulling a read wagon collecting the coats. (See small picture above of her with coats)  That is the heart of Annmarie.  So now to the purpose of this campaign.  Her 8th grade class is visiting Washington D.C., Pennsylvania and New York City this Spring as their 8th grade trip.  It is the trip of a lifetime.  They will be visiting all the places they are learning about this year in American History.  They will visit an Amish community.  They also get to see a live Broadway Show in New York City.  It is a life experience she will never forget.  It breaks my heart that she might have to miss it.  She lives with her mom.  Neither her mom, her dad or we, as her grandparents have the ability to pay for this trip without help.  We will definitely contribute, but it is impossible for any one of us to fund this trip for her.  I hate to think of her missing out on such a wonderful life experience, especially in light of the fabulous, giving young lady that she is.  I am asking you to please consider making a contribution, large or small, to her account to help fund her trip.  The funds will pay for the cost of the trip, meals and incidentals.  In Annmarie style, she is doing her part, fundraising by selling candles and candy bars.  If you are unable to contribute anything, would you be so kind as to “share” her campaign with your friends and family?  It would be so greatly appreciated. Who are we?

WAAW (Working to Advance African Women) Foundation is a 501(c) non-profit social enterprise whose mission is to increase the pipeline of African women in Science, Technology, Engineering and Math (STEM) related fields, and work to ensure that this talent is engaged in African innovation. We do this through Girls STEM camps (11 - 15years)
column2: Scholarships and mentoring(College girls)
column5: id=101"" rel=""noopener nofollow"" target=""_blank"">African Women in Technology Conferences(Professional Women).

column1: Our Vision
To train and engage African women thought leaders in Science and Technology, who contribute to innovation, economic growth and poverty eradication in Africa.
To empower African women with a strong voice by building STEM communities that strengthen her impact by:
<ul>
• Exposing, motivating and mentoring girls in their pursuit of rewarding careers in science, engineering and technology related fields
• Providing opportunities for education and promoting sustainable technology research and innovation activities for African Women.
• Building vibrant communities that engage girls with role models and mentors to ensure an ever increasing pipeline.

• Promoting communities that bring African women thought leaders and organizations from private industry, academia and governments to share ideas, collaborate build and retain technology capacity in Africa.
Our People
WAAW Foundation is currently run by a group of women who have these in common:
<ul>
• A passion for education.
• A passion for the advancement of women in STEM fields

All the executives work on a voluntary basis, contributing their time and money to the WAAW cause. They are all either women in STEM fields or women in education who see the shortage of women in STEM fields, the need to empower and encourage girls/women to remain or join in STEM innovations in Africa and who are eager to give back to the continent (Africa) they grew up in.
What our Scholarship program has achieved so far?
Since 2008, we have awarded five scholarships to African girls to enable them continue to go to school and get an education.
<ol>
• Lillian Kong'ani from Kenya
• Chinenye Ezeakor from Nigeria
• Celestin Tchande from Cameroun
• Ashabe Katushabe from Uganda
• Lorrine Maleya from Kenya
Why we need your help?

WAAW Foundation needs to continue this noble effort because most African girls do not have many opportunities to pursue their dream or have avenues to help them expand their horizons. Scholarship funds to support the education of college girls in Africa are practically nonexistent!

We are about to launch our 2012 scholarship program on August 1, 2012 but we need to raise $5,000 to ensure that the scholarship initiative can continue. 100% of all funds raised will go towards the scholarship funds. All donations are tax deductible. WAAW executives and scholarship facilitators work on a volunteer basis, many times donating their time and resources as well.
We can no longer sustain this initiative alone. The stakes are high and the demands enormous, so we are asking you for help.

Our scholarship program is aimed at providing timely financial support to academically promising female African Students who are currently in STEM related undergraduate disciplines in an African College or University. Awardees must demonstrate financial need and a strong commitment to participating in building Africa. The initiative also promotes peers networks that provide support and mentoring to ensure completion in their chosen STEM fields. Preference is given to girls impacted by HIV and in their early years of study.

We can no longer sit back and watch dreams crushed! Girls like Chinenye and Ashabe need help to ensure their education continues and is not stalled due to financial reasons. They want to graduate and get out of the poverty that plagues Africa, they want to be able to make a difference in the world. Education is the key that can make it happen for them.
How can you help?
To help us and these African girls, we need your help in various ways such as:
<ul>
• Making a donation to our campaign now.
• Encouraging your friends and/or family to make a contribution.
• Spreading the word by using the Indiegogo share tools.

Even the smallest donation will go a long way to help WAAW Foundation continue with its efforts to keep the dream alive in these girls one girl at a time. So even if we don’t reach our goal, what will be contributed will help in giving a girl a scholarship, if we exceed our goal, more girls will benefit from your generous contributions.
Prizes
Your donations will enable WAAW Foundation Scholarship to continue and earn you
<ol>
• A Facebook/twitter shout out from us and promotion in our newsletter.
• WAAW Foundation T-Shirt (100% Organic)
<li>Custom Handmade African print Wine Bag
• A commemorative bracelet with your initials engraved (maynot be as pictured)
<li>Hand woven Banana Leaf iPad Case
<li>Beautiful Turquoise Hand woven plateau basket
• Recognition as a WAAW Foundation Supporter.Three categories of WAAW Foundation Supporter:
• $100+ basic WAAW Supporter
• $500+ Gold WAAW Supporter
• $1000+ Platinum WAAW Supporter
• Automatic entry into the WAAW Foundation raffle tickets in which prizes currently include:
<li>A three day/four night free stay in any Golden Tulip Hotel in West Africa (Accra or Kumasi in Ghana or Lagos, Enugu or Port Harcourt in Nigeria)
<li>A two night/three day free stay in any Best Western Hotel in North America.
• A spa/salon and facial treatment: $50 SpaFinder gift card to spend in over 7000 spas in the USA along with a hand woven unique bracelet made by Rwandan Women.
• A $50 gift card to Target along with a hand woven unique bracelet made by Rwandan Women.
• Four Free Movie Tickets to any AMC Theater.
Should you have any questions about our campaign or if you would like to find out more about our work, please do not hesitate to email us at editor@waawfoundation.org
Thank you so much from all of us at WAAW Foundation.
Ebele Agu, Media Director/CIO.
